summary: The future of civilization rests in the fate of the One Ring, which has been lost for centuries. Powerful forces are unrelenting in their search for it. But fate has placed it in the hands of a young Hobbit named Frodo Baggins (Elijah Wood), who inherits the Ring and steps into legend. A daunting task lies ahead for Frodo when he becomes the Ringbearer - to destroy the One Ring in the fires of Mount Doom where it was forged.

This trilogy is truly a cinematic masterpiece, and is one I've revisited so often it is more akin to an old friend. In fact I'm sure I could repeat much of these trilogies right from memory. The dedication of Jackson's cast is not only obvious in the movie itself, but behind the scenes interviews further delve into the actresses and actors' epic journey to recreate Tolkien's world meticulously in the New Zealand wilderness. The ethereal and sweeping, unfolding world of middle earth brought to life by Jackson never ceases to draw me in, as well as the Howard Shore's captivating soundtrack. 5 stars is not enough to rate this unageing classic.

Jackson succeeds in translating an influential and imaginative, if dense and dry, novel into something palatable allowing time for a broader audience to understand the environment and characters. he is helped by some excellent technical work – not least in production and sound design, location filming and the evocative music score. The actors deliver authentic performances, with McKellen and Lee standouts as opposing wizards, and there are occasional injections of humour to compensate for the darker material. The spectacular set pieces occasionally feel manufactured, and the CGI is variable. But given the project's scope, Jackson achieved a great deal in pulling off a film that pushed the boundaries of cinema expertise.
The first instalment to the greatest trilogy of all time. The music, cast and directing of this and the following movies in the trilogy are absolute perfection.

I grew up with Tolkien from reading him in grade school. I am an old man now. Throughout the years, I have seen all the cartoons, listened to the books on tape, played with the lead figures in the 1970s as an early teen, etc. Back in early and mid 1970's, there wasn't a ton of LOR imagery and art. It was mostly in your head. This was before the Dungeons and Dragons explosion. Peter Jackson did an excellent version of these books. The characters look just like you imagined as a child reading the books. The introduction of the female elf character, in my opinion, even enhanced the stories and was well acted. I wished Jackson had carried all this quality into The Hobbit series that he made a little too much like a fantasy video game that was all over the place in parts. But that said, these 3 LOR movies are excellent and anyone would be hard pressed to out do them for many, many years to come.

This movie is an instant classic, this year marks its 20th anniversary of this movie. So, I thought it'd be the perfect time to write a review for it! When it comes to fans of the Middle-Earth series (both movies and books) there is one thing most of us can agree on, that being that Peter Jackson basically did just as much for J.R.R. Tolkien's stories as J.R.R. Tolkien himself. This movie has aged amazingly well in my opinion, the VFX & SFX both hold up today. FOTR is the perfect first act to a three-part story while telling a fantastic and well-fleshed-out story itself, it has the perfect mix of whimsical and dark fantasy. It handles nine lead characters beautifully without taking from the primary story at hand, it gives each of its leads a moment to shine and gives most of them complete individual story arcs. If you're a fan of the books who's never seen the movies, a fantasy movie fanatic who's never seen the movies, or even someone who's read the books and seen the movies it's worth watching (for the first time or a rewatch). This movie trilogy is one of those rare occasions where something that should've been impossible became a colossal success, this poster boy of the heroes' journey shows what can happen when you are passionate enough about something.

The opening act to the definitive fantasy series of our age is just terrific. It's long but dense and very entertaining, with just the right mix of action, wit, pathos, and grand spectacle. Director/co-writer Peter Jackson and his production team bring Tolkien's words to vivid life, immersing us in a Middle Earth that feels at once fantastical yet organic and earthy. The location shooting in Jackson's native New Zealand is often stunning. The cast sparkles across the board, from Viggo Mortensen's reluctant hero, to Elijah Wood's curious and brave Hobbit, to Christopher Lee's menacing turn as the evil wizard Saruman. Sean Bean, Orlando Bloom, a blustery John Rhys-Davies, and especially Sean Astin make great fellowship mates. Ian McKellen is just grand as the wise and weary Gandalf. But two of the best moments go to the women in this tale, Liv Tyler and the luminous Cate Blanchett. What sets this apart from other inferior fantasy fare is the gravitas of the story. Death isn't greeted with one-liners, but with fear and grief. Each loss in the journey is deeply felt. The victories--small and large--are thrilling. It's a sweeping epic, one that gets us engrossed and involved, and makes us anticipate the next chapter of this saga

As close to perfection in film as you are likely to get...  Whilst the film makes changes to the book, some of which certainly weaken the film and do not add to Tolkien's masterpiece, overall the producers realized the importance of respecting and honoring Tolkien.... Whereas the god-awful Rings of Powers did the opposite, Jackson and his crew tried to adhere as closely as possible to the book and the result is a breathtaking film which captures the beauty and heart of Tolkien's great work.

The Fellowship of the Ring: Not just a Movie, but the Door to another Dimension
The first part of the Lord of the Rings trilogy, the Fellowship of the Rings opened the door to a whole new world for me. I'd never read any of Tolkien's books when I saw the film for the first time at the theatre and, now that I've read them, in retrospect I think being a neophyte to the mythology made my LOTR movie experience all the more miraculous.

I loved The Two Towers and Return of the King almost as much as FOTR, but not quite, because seeing Fellowship for the first time was like taking a journey to a fabulous new place and meeting incredible new friends that you don't want to leave. I've never felt anything quite like what this epic evoked in me. It was akin to being a child again, with that tireless sense of wonder and enjoyment of each and every moment, maybe because as a child you are discovering your surroundings, and whatever age you are, when you watch the Fellowship of the Ring you are rendered in awe upon being introduced to the purity and beauty of Middle Earth and darkly enthralled by the majesty of Eisengard, Saruman, Sauron and all of their mighty malice. One of the things that makes this movie so special (and there are so many!) is that you fall in love not only with the "good" characters, but also with the "evil" ones. For example, Christopher Lee was amazing as Saruman, and I can't imagine the movie without him.

Some films that might be comparable to the Lord of the Rings trilogy are: The Fifth Element, the Star Wars Trilogy parts IV, V and VI (forget the newer prequels), the Matrix trilogy (especially the first part), Interview with a Vampire, the Legend of Sleepy Hollow (with Johnny Depp), Logan's Run and The Island. They are all excellent movies and works of art that weave that movie magic that keeps you spellbound and entranced for the duration of their runtime.

But after seeing The Fellowship of the Ring, I knew I had found the movie by which I would judge all other movies. Based on J.R.R. Tolkien's beloved books, Peter Jackson has set a new standard in the industry of cinema, one that I honestly think has not and won't be surpassed, at least not in my lifetime, not even by PJ himself.

It is truly an instant classic that will stand the test of time and be loved by generations to come. God Bless Tolkien and Jackson and everyone involved in the conception and making of this film, for creating a world that is at my fingertips, only takes the touch of a button to go to whenever I want, and makes me forget everything else.

The Fellowship of The Ring is a solid beginning to a great trilogy. It has all the ingredients that make for a great first film. The ending leaves you satisfied but also wanting more. Most of the film is dedicated to developing the world and characters. The main plot point takes place at the middle of the movie where The Fellowship team up. I have never read the books, so I cant really tell which parts are additions and how good those additions are. All I can say is every part of the movie serves in world building, expanding the plot or character development. So even if there are any additions, they are most probably good ones.

I should probably mention the score. It is one of the highlights of the film and one of my favorite movie scores of all time. The Shire tune is sweet and innocent. As the film progress, just like the characters the tune grows. The Fellowship theme is brave and filled with hope. Sauron's theme also fits his character. It is terrifying and commanding. The other movies also have some standout themes. The battle scenes are epic in every sense of the word. The CGI and practical effects are also really good and hold up after even 20 years.

Almost every character in the fellowship is a great one. Not every character has an arc, but not everyone needs to. Some characters change over the course of all three movies, which perfectly suits them. Boromir has a perfect arc. He is selfish at first, but at the end of the film he sacrifices his life to save the Hobbits. The editing, sound design and cinematography are also stunning. It's a really good film overall.

J.R.R Tolkein's books are wonderful, with memorable characters, an enchanting atmosphere, strong narrative and dialogue and an epic story. Peter Jackson's trilogy mayn't be necessarily true to them, but it does have the memorable characters, the epic story and enchanting atmosphere that the books do. The Fellowship of the Ring is probably the weakest of the three, but it is a very solid start. It is I agree slower in pace to the other two, and there are some talky scenes that drag it down a tad.

However, I cannot deny that this is a great film. One of the many strong assets of this picture are the visuals. The cinematography is marvellous, the costumes are splendid, the effects are great, the makeup is immaculate and the scenery is fantastic especially with Rivendell which was like a Utopia. There is also the score, what an amazing score. As much as I do like Howard Shore, his scoring for the Lord of The Rings trilogy is his most memorable for me and probably his most complex as well. There are so many beautiful and haunting parts here, sometimes even at the same time, as well as the charming Hobbits theme, the ethereal theme played while at Rivendell and the sinister bombastic sounds while at Mordor.

Now I am not going to say that Peter Jackson is a bad director or an outstanding director, but he has directed some wonderful films especially Heavenly Creatures, and this is no exception, where he does a very capable job directing. The story still has its epic scope, with standouts being the confrontation between Gandalf and Sarouman, the scene in the mines with Balrok and Boromir's death scene. I also liked the pursuit of Frodo and Arwyn and Frodo with the Black Riders which was beautifully shot. Then there is the dialogue, which on the whole is excellent, Gandalf in my personal opinion gets the best of it.

And the acting is very good. I do think Frodo is developed more in the sequels than here, but Elijah Wood does do a likable enough job here, while Sean Astin's bumbling yet well meaning persona suits Sam well. Cate Blanchett is a lovely Galadriel, and Liv Tyler is stunning as Arwyn. And then there is Christopher Lee, whose presence always ensures that the performance is going to be good, and indeed it was, and Ian Holm is very good as Bilbo. Sean Bean also does well with Boromir, and John Rhys Davies is a welcome presence. Aragorn like Frodo is developed more in the sequels than here, here he is more brooding and charismatic above all else. Not a bad thing really, as Viggo Mortenssen does do that very well. The standout though is Ian McKellen, who is an absolute revelation as Gandalf, the delivery to the camera, the delivery of the lines, perfectly judged. In fact the only real weak link in the cast is Orlando Bloom, yes he is dashing and handsome, but in the process he does come across as a little uncharismatic and bland.

In conclusion, a great start. 9/10 Bethany Cox

My first time watching the MOST acclaimed series of all time! Strap in and take on this 3 hour film with me!

First thing to be noticed is the narration, and for good reason. Not only is it the very first part of the film, but it's seriously great! The accent and the expression adds so much to the tone of what begins to unfold before your eyes and it's truly wonderful.

Also, this costuming. Holy cow it's gorgeous I mean even the horses have dope costumes on. _ did not miss on these costumes I was blown away with every single character that entered the screen.

While the CGI is quite laughable, the film is still visually stunning. Even when you realize that it's a green screen of the poorer quality, the image is still gorgeous. Cinematography is great across the board and I'm surprised at how much detail was added into all the aspects of this film. Let me say it again, this cinematography is GREAT. Some shots made my eyes widen, others made me audibly gasp. Beautiful.

I would be lying if I said the choreography in the fight scenes wasn't insane. The fights (while repetitive) are awesome. Easily the most entertaining part of the entire film!

Also good Lord this score is magical! It would give me goosebumps at times and would make me feel unsettled at others… I love the way music adds to a film, and this score is a prime example of that. Totally blown away by this orchestra! As the credits rolled, I just sat and listened to the gorgeous music. Such an amazing OST.

While the film is extremely dramatic and focuses on its dark parts a lot, it's not without comedy. There's a lot of "nose-laugh" lines and even a few laugh out loud lines here and there so it really does break the almost constant tension throughout the entire three hours. I love a film that can mix drama in with comedy (which is why I love Bong Joon-Ho so much) so it's no wonder I enjoyed this!

I enjoyed it! It's emotional, it's action packed, it's gorgeous. I'm not sure why people give it 5 stars but hey films are subjective. I can't wait to watch the rest of this trilogy!

Also DANGGG that boy Gandalf is olddd and homeboy runs MAD fast! Dude needs to join the NFL or maybe start running the 800 in track

When the genre fantasy is mentioned, The Lord of the Rings is the first thought that comes to many peoples minds as it captures all the desired qualities required to be considered in that genre. The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) starts off the viewers experience with this trilogy in an absolutely outstanding way, leading from place to place, introducing things for the first time to the viewer along with the characters and never once failing to entertain.

The reason for The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) being so engaging is that it follows such an engaging story with well developed characters, who all get their individual moments or in a group dynamic.

Despite this films (and it's sequels) famous lengthy-runtime, it isn't felt compared to other movies as they provide a reason for using such length in executing engaging dialogue and a well thought-out story.

This is my favorite movie of the series by quite a wide margin. They did an impeccable job introducing audiences to the source material and inserting enough climactic events in the second and third acts that it didn't feel like a stretched-out origin story at any moment. Every pleasing visual & musical detail was at its freshest, there are not so many jarring uses of deus ex machina and Frodo hasn't yet been reduced to a worthless obstacle that Sam must overcome. The entire trilogy is awesome as a whole, but this section of it shines brighter than the rest for me.

Peter jackson is one of the best directors in terms of good budget use, the director probably learned that in his early career directing great trahs movies, and in "The Lord of the Rings" it's no different, peter makes a film of almost 4 hours grand, with impeccable costumes and makeup, great visual effects for the time and a wide range of magnificent backdrops and screen compositions, by comparison, the same year also came out Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone which cost 38 million more, although "The Lord of the Rings" seems much more expensive.

I didn't read the classic JRR Tolkien book to know how it was transposed to the screen, but even with a long film time, we have zero waste, we have a story that constantly grows, full of arcs and a past that transports mythology, all of this combined with a classic and very well constructed hero arc that unfolds in a great intro drama, the film has four acts and a short last act that already leaves a plot for the sequel.

The entire art direction of the film is exquisite, the feature film, which is already over 20 years old, leaves some special effects dated, it's true, but at the time it was very surprising and still convinces today, especially in its costumes and makeup, which are still great today. , photography and the use of the green background still work reasonably well, and the soundtrack is a show on its own, showing the inner emotion of each nucleus through its melodies.

Peter Jackson works well not only the visual and script factor, but also works the small layers, such as obsession, fear and overcoming, and also knew how to squeeze the most out of his cast of actors, taking magnificent performances, such as de Ian McKellen for example.

The film is very well worked in its most diverse layers, every shot is very well executed and formidable, the weakest point perhaps is the lack of coherence, violence and the sobriety tone of the work, which changes its state of mind constantly, but these are details that do not bother this work at all, which amuses, entertains and enchants to this day. GRADE 8.5/10

Well... I'm afraid that this movie is by far the most disappointing film that I've ever sat down to watch. I came in with the greatest of expectations, as I've seen countless amazing reviews, articles, and even been directly told of the praise that this movie "deserves". How it's "better than the book", "truly riveting", "the greatest action movie to date", and so on. However, I simply cannot agree with any of those claims.  I think Peter cheapened much of the story, even beyond that of what's expected from compressing 423 pages down to 178 minutes worth of film *I watched the theatrical version*.  Since this review is already getting very long I'm going to list out the changes that Peter made that I think were for the worse. 
-Merry was re-written to become a Pippin part 2, which is especially terrible since in the original story they were quite different. Merry starts out responsible and leader-like then has to deal with feelings of loneliness and usefulness. While Pippin starts out naive and mistake-ridden then learns to become responsible and valiant. 
-Elrond and Galadriel are very dislikeable. I could smell their superiority complex through my screen.  
-Gandalfs already 'not perfectly' written pre-fellowship journey becomes even worse. Like why go to Saruman before safely escorting the Hobbit to Rivendell? Why not go help the Hobbit directly after getting to Rivendell? What happened to the letter?  
-Aragorn and Gandalfs relationship is too mysterious. You don't see them interact with each other much, Gandalfs speaks of no importance with Aragon, and all that makes Aragorn's presence at the prancing pony even more convenient. Furthermore, why weren't the Hobbits more suspicious of him when they met?  
-Nazgul nerfed? Why was Aragorn able to solo 5 of the Nazgul with nothing but a sword and torch? In the book, they quickly fled because they thought that Frodo had no chance at surviving the wound, but in the movie, they stayed to fight with Aragorn for a bit before getting chased out because Aragorn was destroying them. 
-The Gandalf v Saruman fight was maybe the worst fight scene I've ever seen from such a big movie. Force pushing each other around with sticks, how exciting. 
-Elves were just cringy, with the blurring filter and ugly language, it was just too much. 
-Legolas, Gimli, and Boromir were less explained. In the books Legolas comes to tell about Golums escape, Gimli comes to discuss Saurons offer to the Dwarves on the lonely mountain, and Boromir comes to find counsel on his and Faramir's dreams. But in the movie, they are just there because they are important figures in their kingdoms.   
Although I have plenty of gripes with the movie I think it still did a fine job. I thought the production quality was outstanding, even for 2021's standards. I also like that Arwen became more prevalent in the story, although her being the one sent to help Aragorn and the Hobbits makes no sense but exploring her and Aragorn's relationship early on was a definite plus to the story.  So overall I don't think it's bad but it stacks nowhere near the original story and I can't believe that anyone can say otherwise, but I seem to be in the minority so maybe I'm just wrong.

This movie is an instant classic, this year marks the 20th anniversary of this movie. So, I thought it'd be the perfect time to write a review for it! When it comes to fans of the Middle-Earth series (both movies and books) there is one thing most of us can agree on, that being that Peter Jackson basically did just as much for J.R.R. Tolkien's stories as J.R.R. Tolkien himself. This movie has aged amazingly well in my opinion, the VFX & SFX both hold up today. FOTR is the perfect first act to a three-part story while telling a fantastic and well fleshed out story itself, it has the perfect mix of whimsical and dark fantasy. It handles nine lead characters beautifully without taking from the primary story at hand, it gives each of its leads a moment to shine and gives most of them complete individual story arcs. If you're a fan of the books who's never seen the movies, or a fantasy movie fanatic who's never seen the movies, or even someone who's read the books and seen the movies it's worth watching (for the first time or a rewatch). This movie trilogy is one of those rare occasions where something that should've been impossible became a colossal success, this poster boy of the heroes' journey shows what can happen when you are passionate enough about something.

I had begun watching The Lord of the Rings because of all the memes and references in other movies and shows. And that was probably an excellent decision. It has been a year since I have watched these and since the story is distributed among all the three movies, I have decided that I will talk about something unique each of them. In total these movies clock over 10 hours, and I can imagine how much the fans of the book must have loved it when they learnt they are getting so much content from a book they love reading so much.

The Fellowship of the Ring is the very first one of the movies which basically kickstarts the adventure. It is amazing to see how much content this movie has in spite of the fact that the entire backstory was narrated in the first two minutes of the beginning. There are a lot of things to talk about in this. The movie created a font style, a score and a colour palette that fits along with the scenes of the battle that made it look so suspenseful. As the scene was going on I was very attentive to hear everything that happens throughout. And this was just the first two minutes of the 3 hour movie.

Afterwards the scene transitioned to the otherwise peaceful Hobbiton. It was a very interesting transition, that showed how on one hand the races are fighting each other for getting control over the Middle Earth, while on the other hand there are a bunch of peace loving Hobbits who are just into their day to day lives. They always have very wholesome reactions when they see Gandalf, which is the reason why it creates a stark contrast from what is about to happen after they leave Hobbiton. Although Bilbo was a good friend of Gandalf and Gandalf had come all the way to celebrate his birthday, he didn't feel that Bilbo was a trustworthy person because he was also attached to the ring. As a result he decided to send his nephew Frodo, his friend Sam and two other Hobbits to help dispose of the ring.

The ring is also something I'd like to talk about here, since it is in this movie that the ring and its effects have been talked about the most. The ring is something that appeals to anyone who has desires, but once it is worn it ends up tormenting the wearer. The subtle message that this sends us is the consequence of a moment's greed. Not everyone has the ability to hold their temptation, which is the reason why the Hobbits are specifically sent to dispose of it. Frodo himself has the urge to wear it twice, the reason being that he wanted to save himself. At one moment he wears it accidentally during a bar fight, which makes him see the Eye of Modor and makes him vulnerable. If one is able to get over their desires and focus on what makes their life easy, there will be no need of such temptations. This is what the ring tells us.

And afterwards they go to Rivendell, which is, simply said, the most beautiful place I have ever seen in my whole life in any movie! Over there they create The Fellowship of the Ring, which goes to destroy the ring in the lava at the Mountain of Doom. Now I won't get too much into the story since I want to keep this review spoiler-free, so I'm just gonna talk about how beautiful all the scenes from this movie are. Seeing them reminded me of my childhood, reading nursery rhymes and fairy tales. I always looked at the pictures and imagined this is what those places must have looked like. Every location from this movie looks like it could be one of those 19th century paintings. It's amazing to see such places are still left in this world that have not been destroyed as of yet.

The movie, or should I say the trilogy, has really gone hard with the details. They chose to make the maps, the fonts, the detailed lore, all the cities from the Middle Earth and even the easter eggs which added a lot of lore to the movie. Every scene from the movie looks like a painting, which is not something which can be said about most adventure fantasy movies. It has the feeling of an RPG game to it, or at least that's how I feel it. It's something of a Skyrim of all movies. For the fans this must have felt like a dream coming true. Things like these should be made for all fantasy movies, which have begun looking underworked simply because of the existence of this movie.

The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring is not a movie that I may want to watch again because of how long it was and the fact that it is nothing in itself unless the other two parts are also combined, but this is also for a good thing because of the fond memories that this movie has left for me. Personally this was the most memorable movie for me among the trilogy. It was because of how rich and detailed this movie was that gave me the confidence of watching the other two movies as well, something I rarely do otherwise. There are many iconic movies like The Godfather, Jurassic Park and Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs which I did like, but they didn't give me the courage to continue. This is going to be one of those classical movies that I'd remember for life.

The most troublesome start to the trilogy, as the first book still has some of the more outlandish "hobbit" type characters, pointless poetry and a lack of pacing.   But the Jackson crew improved on it, and gave it much more tension and gravity.  Plus the Balrog scene delivered one of the most famous memes ever.

While it's not a flawless adaptation or work of cinema, The Fellowship of the Rings is Master-Class in virtually every respect.  The story is very clear and the stakes are very well established, so you feel for the characters when they are in danger, and how they are put into danger, as well as how they get out of it, is almost always very well detailed.  The acting is outstanding with almost every performer, and the emotion from shot-to-shot and scene-to-scene is carried out perfect in terms of consistency.  The Cinematography, CGI and Production Design are absolutely amazing (well, the CGI was for 2001) and the Musical Score and Sound Mixing are better than most movies I can think of.  It's an absolute home-run in regards to both its artistic and technical merits, and Peter Jackson's perfectly done Directing proves just how powerful it is when a filmmaker truly BELIEVES in the world they are creating.  And in all honesty, I cannot think of anything genuinely bad in regards to this film, in either cut (Theatrical or Extended), no matter how small.  It's easily one of the best Swords and Sorcery films ever made, and having watched it without reading the book first, I was absolutely enamored every step of the way, and when the characters underwent deep emotional losses, I was completely misty-eyed with them.  There is no such thing as Cinematic Perfection, but there are a small handful of movies that do come as close as possible, and this one is one of those.

'The Lord of the Rings' is yet another film series that I am incredibly late to viewing, at least I've finally got around to it... albeit almost twenty years on from this film's release.

'The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring' is delightful. I never know what to expect from a film that goes on for nearly three hours, the pacing has to be near perfection for it to work - and boy does it here. The run time flew by, which is always a terrific sign.

I love a load of things about this, the one that actually sticks out most is the outstanding score. Music can play a huge part in how much I enjoy a film, so I'm delighted to say that the score is here is fantastic. That is by no means the only positive, obviously.

The cast are excellent. Elijah Wood gives a strong performance in the lead role. I've seen Wood in others things down the years and have actually found him a bit hit-and-miss, but here he is very good. Elsewhere, I really enjoyed watching Viggo Mortensen's character.

Away from those two, there are a whole host of noteworthy cast members. Orlando Bloom, or Will Turner to me, is involved, as are the likes of Ian McKellen and Sean Bean. I also liked Liv Tyler in her role.

The look of the film is spectacular, and has aged extremely well even to this day. Everything from the cinematography to the costumes is brilliant, those two things really make the film come alive - helped by the aforementioned score, of course.

Very eager to check out the sequels, prequels and, eventually, the upcoming television series.

The Fellowship of the Ring originally released in 2001 and has stood the test of time. A brilliant foundation of the trilogy filled with spectacular landscapes, an epic musical score, and superb acting. 

First, for being a 3 hour movie (theatrically) it is paced quite well. It starts a brief history of the ring of power before turning to the quiet peace of The Shire. After Frodo and Sam leave the Shire, we get to witness some stunning cinematography throughout the gorgeous Middle Earth. Honestly it's like Planet Earth with orcs just absolutely breathtaking. Even the set pieces match the wonder of the world between Rivendell and the Mines of Moria. 

Now, what elevates great movies to master class can be the score. With the entire trilogy, Howard Shore crafted some of the most moving pieces of music to make their way into movies. Just listening to the soundtrack will take you on the journey of the Fellowship. Adding it into the movie just isn't fair to other movies. Perfection. 

The Lord of the Rings would not be as good as it is without solid acting. A few favorites: Sean Bean as Boromir, Sean Astin as Sam, Viggo Mortensen as Aragorn, and Ian McKellen as Gandalf. Nearly 20 years later and I still cry on the floor when Boromir gives his life for the Fellowship. When Gandalf falls in the Mines and we all need a break to handle our emotions. Don't even get me started on the music in those scenes. 

The Fellowship of the Ring is an epic that has aged like a fine wine. Cinematography, music, and solid acting are just the tip of the iceberg in this expertly crafted tale. If you've never seen it before it is a must watch. If you have seen it, then it's about time to watch it again. One does not simply find flaws in this perfect movie.

The first entry in this epic JRR Tolkien saga is a fantasy masterpiece of cinema. What Peter Jackson (Director) has accomplished at this time was nearly impossible. The visual effects were beyond its time and creating the world of Middle Earth was some of the best world building in cinema history. The cast and ensemble all are at the most perfect you can be playing these beloved characters. This is the first of a trilogy of films but it stands on its own as one of the best fantasy films of all time.
Beautiful movie in every way...

I recently rewatched this movie in IMAX and wow it is still incredible. Peter Jackson knocks it out of the park introducing the world of Middle Earth in this first movie. I could go on and on about all of the things I love about this movie, but I'll just name a few. The score (music) in the movie is not only terrific, but also matches the movie better than almost any movie I've seen. Coupled with beautiful cinematography and a few other elements, it helps create beautiful, sad, touching, inspiring, and heroic scenes in the movie. The VFX still looks good in most scenes and even in scenes where it isn't great, it's still not bad. Along those lines, the makeup is great. Watching it 20 years later, the orcs look like orcs and not men in makeup and costumes. As mentioned earlier, the cinematography is outstanding. All of the acting is terrific and the characters are very likable. Unlike most movies, there isn't a single character that I dislike in this movie. I could say much more but I'll sum this all up by saying that I think this is an incredible action/adventure/fantasy movie that has aged very well. 5/5.

Arguably the most epic film of all time, only really contending with the godfather, Peter Jackson creates a perfect synthesis of music, emotional and imaginative storytelling, innovative cgi, spectacular action, & memorable characters, cementing The Lord of the  Rings as a landmark in both literature and in cinema.

The first part of Tolkien's classic fantasy trilogy brought to the screen, with extra scenes expanding the story. I'd seen the theatrical cut before, probably around the time it came out, but it had been so long and I was told the extended editions are the only real way to watch the movies. It's good high fantasy, which can mean it's a little whimsical and silly at times (especially the Hobbits and Elves). The slow-mo didn't age very well, but the CGI and practical effects still hold up really well for the most part. I was worried watching the extended version that I'd get bored, but I was glad to find I did not as the story is well paced and engaging. Though we did end up splitting it over two days. The casting is spot on. I enjoyed it but it didn't wow me. And maybe that's just because I'm spoiled by modern day storytelling or I'm so familiar with the property, I dunno.  It was fun running across all the meme moments.

The characters, the Elvish language, the setting, everything intruiged me. It was artistically and originally beautiful, not at all what I expected. Peter Jackson was absolutely the right person to do this...well done man!

An adventurous and entertaining first chapter of a trilogy, combined with Jackson's direction, the script he co-wrote with Walsh and Boyens, the performances of the cast, Shore's score, Lesnie's cinematography, Gilbert's editing, Major's production design, Hennah and Lee's set decoration, Dickson and Taylor's costume design, action sequences, sound design and visual effects, The Fellowship Of The Ring starts this trilogy off with action packed and visually stunning storytelling!!!

Lord Of The Rings: The Fellowship Of The Ring is honestly a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got a brilliant plot, it's pretty much about this young hobbit, who's called Frodo Baggins (Elijah Wood) he ends up finding the one ring that belongs to the Dark Lord Sauron.

So, he begins his journey with eight companions to a place called Mount Doom, this is pretty much the only place where the ring can be destroyed.

The cast are all honestly amazing as their characters throughout this movie and all of the dialogue from the characters feels natural and it doesn't feel forced at all.

Also, the movie's got some beautifully smooth cinematography from Andrew Lesnie. The way he's shot this movie is honestly beautiful and he captures the scenes brilliantly.

The action sequences throughout this movie are very clever, violent and very unique and they're all showcased pretty well throughout this movie.

The movie's even got a beautifully composed score from Howard Shore, it's composed so well and it's such a beautiful soundtrack.

Finally, all of the orcs look very rough and very gruesome throughout this movie but I actually adore the way they look throughout this movie, it really adds to their characters.

Overall, Lord Of The Rings: The Fellowship Of The Ring is honestly a masterpiece and a half. It's got a brilliant plot, amazing characters, very good dialogue, beautiful cinematography, very clever and very violent action sequences. The movie's even got some very gruesome looking orcs and a score which is beautifully composed.

I'd honestly recommend this movie, if you enjoy fantasy/action movie's with a brilliant plot, amazing acting, very clever and very unique action sequences. This is the movie for you, it's honestly worth the watch.

The Fellowship of The Ring is a visual and cinematic masterpiece that perfectly fits with an extraordinary plot. The visuals pull you into Peter Jackson's vision of Middle Earth, and after being dragged in you are then attached to a plotline of elves and hobbits. The characters of this film are perfectly created to allow you to connect so amazingly to the story. The visuals, the plotline, the characters everything about this film help to make the journey this masterpiece takes you on an incredible journey that is fueled by emotional attachments to the characters and plot. You gain such attachment to the characters that you go through every emotion imaginable from fear and worry to happiness and relief. The world that Peter Jackson has created is home to one of the greatest trilogies of all time.

It's great start. Peter Jackson knows how to shoot a film, and it sort of shows how the characters begin to leave the tiny crevice they live in. By the end of the film, Frodo and Sam, and really the rest of the cast have left the crevice proper and are about to enter into a different world. Which leads to some compelling character drama. The special effects still hold up. And both Sauron, Saruman, and the ring wraiths are such  menacing villains. The only fault it has is, towards the end of the film, it falls into the "Batman Begins" syndrome filming much of its action in closeups and shaky cam, which made it hard for me to follow. But overall, it's a fantastic movie.

Almost 20 years after they were made, The Lord of the Rings trilogy remain classics of our time.  The films set a standard that many have tried to copy, but few have reached.  Quite simply, these films are story telling on an epic scale.  They have had a huge influence on popular culture.  For me, what really sets these films apart from other great films is that Lord of the Rings contains no sex or swearing, and yet they appeal to all, not feeling at all like a children's story - quite an achievement.

I absolutely loved this film and this is one of the best films I have ever seen. This, in my opinion, is the best work of worldbuilding of all time and the whole trilogy has the best worldbuilding in my opinion from Gondor to the Shire to Mordor it just has an atmosphere from the score to the location/set to the acting and the costumes and the script it all contributes to the amazing atmosphere no other film can achieve. This has the best score of all time in my opinion and it is one of the most iconic and whenever I hear it I just get happy because of the happy nature of the song I clearly love it. I think this film has the most perfect cast of all time from Elijah Wood being Frodo to Ian McKellan being Gandalf to Sean Austin being Sam to Viggo Mortensen being Aragorn just perfectly cast. On top of the iconic score and characters, you have so many iconic scenes like the, you shall not pass scene and many more. This film creates a sense of nostalgia for Gandalf it has something to do with wise people like you know them but you don't know them it,s weird and he is one of my all time favorite film characters along with Gollem/Smeagol. I love the story so much at the base of it its just Frodo returning the ring to Mount Doom but they make it so much more complicated for the better of the story. This film really holds up with today's blockbusters and even better than a lot of them I like this trilogy more than the Hobbit as much do but I didn't think I would like this at all but the whole trilogy made it into my top three films of all time and that really surprised me even though I like this trilogy more the Hobbit trilogy will hold a special place in my heart. I swear Andy Serkis deserves an oscar by now he has such a stacked career and he does better than some actors working now with his motion-capture acting to the movements and the facial expressions he has to do for this and the plant of the apes trilogy. This film has so many memorable lines and iconic lines like the one Gandalf said to Frodo when he said he can't carry the ring he said "All we have to decide is what to do with the time given to us." he is so wise. One of my favorite scenes of all time is the one when Gandalf and Frodo are having a heart to heart moment when they are stuck and dont know which way to go it is such a real scene and will stick with you till the end and that is where that line came from it. The action scenes really hold up with the action today and that is kinda surprising.

I love the use of practical effects with makeup instead of green screening most it in this trilogy and I wish that they used practical effects in the Hobbit trilogy it would have made that so much better. The sound mixing and the sound design is amazing with all of the orcs and the creatures it still holds up with today's films. I don't think they could have chosen a better filming location than New Zealand it fits the Middle-Earth atmosphere. I love the subtle color grading in each scene from the night time sequences to the day it looks amazing. The script is amazing and one of the best in my opinion. There is so much character development in this and I absolutely love it. If there is one thing that got snubbed in the trilogy it was Elijah Wood's acting it is actually really good and everyone did the best. The editing is pretty good mixed with the score adds so much tension and suspense in each scene. Overall I absolutely loved this movie and would recommend it to anyone.

The first entry into The Lord of the Rings trilogy is so good at establishing this fantastical world and immersing you within in it and with and extremely enjoyable plot and characters to watch go through this epic journey is so satisfying and sucks you in to ensure you come back to watch the next two. Fellowship is world building at its finest, allowing this world of Middle-Earth to be set up and explored through so many sets, seeing so many new creatures, and battling against the darkest evils in this made-up world. Personally, I'm not a huge Lord of the Rings fan and don't know anything not shown within this trilogy of films, but I can admire the craft, creativity, and dedication to adapting the novels into the quintessential fantasy movies. Everything about it is so great, with only minor critiques of the final product.

This is one of my favorite movies ever created, it is a masterpiece with no flaws whatsoever. I love this story and thought that Peter Jackson's cinematic interpretation of the novels was even better than the original source material, in my own personal opinion. This movie got so many things right, every actor in this whole movie was amazing, the script is exceptionally well written with emotional investment for every character, the effects were almost all practical with real actors and real sets that they built which all look stunning especially for 2001, and Howard Shore's score for this film is almost as good as John Williams Star Wars score, it is emotionally moving and has me in tears, it also really adds to the way the story plays out, Its almost as if each song is it's own little story even, I adore it and think that it is one of the best originally composed scores for a movie ever and Howard Shore is definitely deserving of the Oscar he received. Andrew Lesnie shot this movie perfectly, the way that the shots are constructed really speak to you and adds more tension to the story, he rivals Roger Deakons and he definitely deserved the Oscar that he won for this film. Elijah Wood has a career in acting thanks to these movies, and he is really good, Sean Astin is my personal favorite and he gives an amazing performance and I see him as good ol' Samwise Gamgee, I really don't understand how he didn't get tons of other acting roles because of this, he is so damn good I still can't believe it. Billy Boyd and Dominic Monaghan are both pretty good as well providing some good comic relief and great companionship to Frodo and Sam. Orlando Bloom and John Rhys-Davies have great chemistry together as the oddball BFF's of the group, I enjoyed seeing both of them, particularly together. Viggo Mortensen was phenomenal, he takes his role so seriously and he blends behind Aragorn so well, that I really believe that's who he is, I loved him so much in this movie. Sean Bean is a very underrated actor who performed very well for this movie, I loved seeing the struggle he had, he was fighting himself the whole time and you could feel that start to seep through with his masterful performance, this is perhaps the best performance of his career, his death is one of the most memorable and emotional deaths in cinematic history, it is played out perfectly and redeems the character of his previous faults, Boromir is one of my favorites of this whole trilogy. Ian McKellen was dazzling, he was so good I can't put it into words, he was the best written and acted character and he is iconic, he made Gandalf one of the most recognized and important characters in all of cinema. I love the entire mines of Moria sequence, it is so intense and exciting, the camera angles, the music, the gorgeous cinematography, and the great practical effects all contribute to an amazing action sequence that doesn't let up, and it ends with the very emotional "death" of Gandalf, I know that he comes back, but I still tear up every time. This movie is my personal favorite of the three and has no problems, I exclusively watch the extended edition and at three and a half hours, I never get bored and I still want more. I have never read any of J. R. R. Tolkien's writings and my understanding of the story of The Lord of the Rings going into this film was very limited. Because of that I did find myself lost at points but the basic statements that the film made were enough to tether into and the likable characters kept me afloat as I attempted to remain engaged with the film. Knowing that there are two more films of considerable length to get through in order to complete this saga does daunt me but I enjoyed this film more than I expected to. The special effects and world building were great and although the wild shifts in tone take some getting used to the dark subject matter is dealt with better than in say Game of Thrones.

Frodo Baggins, Elijah Wood, is sent off with the One Ring, an all powerful ring created by the evil Sauron, Sala Baker, to control humans, by Gandalf, Ian McKellen, after it's longtime owner Bilbo Baggins, Ian Holm, becomes enchanted by it. He brings his close friend Samwise Gamgee, Sean Astin, along with him on the journey and they are joined by Merry, Dominic Monaghan, and Pippin, Billy Boyd. They meet Aragorn, Viggo Mortensen, on their way to Rivendell and when Frodo is stabbed with a Morgul blade he is rescued by Aragorn's girlfriend Arwen, Liv Tyler. Meanwhile Gandalf is imprisoned by Saruman, Christopher Lee, who has become enthralled by the ring but he is able to escape on an eagle's back and join the men. Frodo is forced to continue his journey with the ring because he is the only person with enough restraint not to fall prey to Sauron.

The most impressive part of the film was it's production design and the innovative special effects used. The world the film is set in appears real despite the fantastical images that the book presumably asks Jackson to conjure. The sight of miniature Elijah Wood speaking to a monolithic Ian McKellen is fascinating and although the special effects used to show Sauron and the nature of Rivendell haven't aged well they are still admirable for the time. If this element of the film wasn't up to snuff then the film would be almost unwatchable but because the sights the film presents are jaw dropping I was able to accept the fantasy of the situation the film presents.

The story itself confused me and there was so much information dropped in during Cate Blanchett's opening narration that it would have been impossible to pick up on it all if you had not read the book. I will not penalize it for that because most people going into the film will have been fans of the book and already know all the backstory the various scenes we see but Jackson does a very good job at providing enough context to understand the scenes for the uneducated viewer. Personally I thought that the most interesting part of the film was the first half because it concerned the personal lives of the characters more than physical battles with fantastical creatures but I think that the film as a whole is fairly entertaining. The end of the film was unsatisfying to me because I felt as though it was the only reason that two characters existed but I suppose that was why there was a sequel.

Mortensen does a good job as Aragorn, he appears authoritative and charming in his role even though he is written as a near-perfect figure. The accents seem to be all over the place but I don't know if that is accounted for in the book and the cast do a very good job of playing broad characters with some humanity. Tyler lacks charisma as a love interest and although she works with terrible dialogue I would have appreciated a romantic heroine with more backbone. 

If I am honest this can be a real chore of a film if you aren't into the source material and I would never have watched if I weren't trying to watch every Best Picture winner ever, the third film in the series is the 2004 winner. It is a film that you should see however if you want to watch essential cinema of the 2000s because it was a major cultural moment and made significant technical advances.

Straight from the book of J. R. R. Tolkien Lord of The Rings: The fellowship of The Ring follows a young hobbit named Frodo Baggins as he is pulled away from his utopian-like society and thrust into a dangerous world of mythical creatures with his trusty friend Samwise Gamgee; they begin an adventure of a lifetime. This adventurous and compelling movie is directed by Peter Jackson and stars Elijah Wood as the main protagonist Frodo Baggins and Sam Astin as his friend Samwise Gamgee, but the acting isnï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)t what makes this movie so great; itï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)s in fact the special effects. The special effects team were highly skilled to use and twist special effects to match the needs of Jacksonï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)s fantasy. One of the great examples is how they used the special effects to portray the actors to be shorter than they actually are. For example Elijah Woodï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)s height is 5ï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)6 but in the movie he is portrayed as 3ï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)6. Another example of the great special effects of the movie is the CGI on the creature Balrog which was made completely from computer graphics along with other creatures makes the monster and creatures seem real. The most prominent and best display of special effects and CGI is on the cursed creature Gollum. With Gollum the special team used new and various methods to make him look as real as possible. With the help of CGI and special effects Jackson has made The Lord of The Rings into a movie to remember.

Watching the theatrical cut again last weekend with my kids, I was blown away at the masterful way characters, scenes, vignettes, narration, flashbacks and all the tools of this sort of fantasy cinematic storytelling are used to give a brilliant, clear and faithful screen depiction of one of the most loved books in the world. Example: "Let's take a shortcut!" "A shortcut to what?" [trips over, lands at the base of a tree and sees...] "Mushrooms" Twenty odd years later we take this film for granted but it was SO brilliantly done. Thanks Fran, Pippa and Peter!!

Voglio fare una recensione unica per questa trilogia cercando di essere il più breve e conciso possibile. Intanto parto col dire che è la Trilogia fantastica per eccellenza, ormai divenuta cult, perfetta sotto quasi ogni aspetto. Ogni cosa è resa al meglio e non ci sono difetti dal punto di vista tecnico; regia di Peter Jackson perfetta, fotografia bellissima e effetti speciali da paura. Le scenografie, le ambientazioni, il trucco e i costumi sono eccellenti. Le musiche e il montaggio delle musiche azzeccatissimi. Dal punto di vista narrativo nulla da dire anche perché non ho letto i libri, purtroppo. Il personaggio che più mi è piaciuto è stato Samvise, interpretato da Sean Astin che è stato semplicemente magnifico; senza di lui Frodo non avrebbe fatto tutto quello che ha fatto, il vero Eroe della trilogia, soprattutto nell'ultimo film ("Il Ritorno del Re"). Spettacolari anche Ian McKellen (Gandalf), che ha regalato diverse perle divenute cult, e Andy Serkis che ha interpretato Gollum, personaggio bello e brutto allo stesso tempo. Di grandissima potenza i dialoghi di Gollum che ha due personalità, Smeagol (il suo nome originale) e appunto Gollum. Ottimi anche gli altri personaggi. Gli ultimi 50 minuti del terzo film sono di una intensità pazzesca, perfetti sotto ogni punto di vista. Tra i tre film ovviamente ho preferito il terzo ma son tutti e tre fantastici, trilogia UNICA firmata Peter Jackson.

A great start to Peter Jackson's classic trilogy, The Fellowship of the Ring translates J.R.R. Tolkien's classic to life and Middle-Earth is wonderfully realized. The performances are great, the battles are tense, the score is great and the visuals AND the cinematography are beautiful. Who wouldn't want to go to New Zealand after seeing this movie? The world-building and sets are really impressive with the complex computer-generated camera movements have you bask in the glory of what I assume is Saruman's evil lair and Rivendell. Plus, there are some really scary scenes that have you wishing the One Ring never ends up in your posession, A great start.

Notwithstanding all the hype it received, the best that can be said about this film and its sequals is that they constitute an adequate adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien's trilogy, albeit marred by overly extended scenes of violence (which will bore most mature viewers) and over-rich digital color saturation, which often gives one the sense that one is watching a cartoon. Ralph Bakshi's more modest (by today's standards) version beats it in terms of creativity and artistic risks, and the old Rankin-Bass cartoon of The Hobbit beats it for charm.

Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring is a phenomenal way to start off the LOTR trilogy that sets a very high standard for the next films! It's a phenomenal adaptation of the famous book by J.R.R Tolkien that Peter Jackson does quite a good job making. Peter Jackson and the two other screenwriters all wrote an amazing adapted screenplay bringing great detail from the book onto the screen. The direction given by Peter Jackson is quite amazing as he captures everything needed, directs large groups of people in some scenes very well and brings the story to life which is why he was perfect for the job. The whole cast is full of a lot of big and good actors that all do a great job with their roles giving great performances. Elijah Wood, Ian McKellen, Viggo Mortensen, Cate Blanchett, Orlando Bloom, Sean Bean, Hugo Weaving, Liv Tyler, Christopher Lee and Sean Astin are all the main people who all were great for their roles and did them successfully. Even though I didn't mention them, the supporting cast also did a great job. The groundbreaking special effects  in the film definitely can't go unnoticed because it's visually outstanding and it's part of what makes the movie as good as it is. Overall, this film totally brings the book to life and is something that fans of the book and people who haven't read it (like me even though I probably should) can definitely enjoy.

The Fellowship of the Ring introduces us to the One Ring, forged by Lord Sauron and filled with dark powers that consumes the one who holds it. The Ring was held by Bilbo Baggins for many years till he decided to give it to his nephew Frodo. The film begins with an old-fashioned storybook introduction, where they narrate the history of the Ring, which was great because I knew nothing about this trilogy. The film centres around Frodo as he embarks on an adventure with his companions, The Fellowship, to Mount Doom to get rid of the Ring. Throughout their adventure, the Ring visibly becomes its own character that is so feared, almost like a prisoner. An inanimate object possessed by an evil force is something you expect to see from a horror movie, but it evidently works better in this genre. The Fellowship is greeted by many creatures, terrifying for the audience but probably beautiful to the filmmakers. The movie is filled with scenic shots that seem to be too good to truly exist in this world. I would be more surprised if the backdrops are not shot in front of a green screen. It contains effects that I did not expect to come from a 2001 movie. I also noticed some kind of resemblance in its production to Game of Thrones. It is of a complex source material but is brought to life as clear as can be. On the contrary, it seems that they left the Saruman storyline unintended, but I could have blinked and missed something. The movie ends with a lot of despair yet so much hope. It does not really have a cliffhanger, but you will still ask "what's next". Overall, The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring beautifully brings to life a story that appeals not only to those who follow the source material, but also to those who do not, and will most likely continue appealing to future generations.

The greatest film of all time: The Lord of the Rings: Fellowship of the Rings delivers on everything that made J.R.R. Tolkien's masterpiece of a book so enjoyable in the first place. I'll first start off with how much I love Peter Jackson's directing style. To turn a book of that magnitude into a movie is just amazing. And on top of that, the way he did it was just... CRAZY! This guy had no business creating a Lord of the Rings film - he had no experience in the genre, he hadn't made a single blockbuster yet, and was specifically in the horror genre scene (apart from Heavenly Creatures). But man did he do it, and did it better than anyone ever could. Beyond just the directing, however, lies a scale that has never been reached before - and probably never will after. The world building is truly astonishing and breathtaking. There is just nothing like it. The writing is also fantastic, and so are the visuals. Man, gives me goosebumps just thinking about it all. Anyways, we also have the acting. Elijah Wood delivers on so many levels. Giving a young actor like him, such a huge role and then succeeding at it so well, is fantastic. Ian McKellen is captivating as Gandalf. He's both sincere and warm. Viggo Mortensen is intense, Sean Astin is moving and Cate Blanchett is magical. Sean Bean gives one of, if not his best performance ever, and the Billy Boyd and Dominic Monaghan combination is just purely fantastic casting. The costume design is also stupidly jaw dropping - it brings so much more realism to the screen. Sometimes I can't believe how great it is. The score is gorgeous as well. Howard Shore created a masterpiece. All in all, this film is spectacular in every way, shape and form. And will go down in history as the best fantasy film of all time, and my favorite film of all time. Give it a try if you haven't - it's well worth your time!

As a big fan of Tolkienian world, I precise that I'm going to review the extended edition movies. I obviously start with The Fellowship of the Ring, my favourite movie of the three, and I specify why: I found the novel too slow and a little bit boring, but this movie has been capable of gripping me and I appreciated that. A description of the plot wouldn't be necessary if one had read the novel, but let's write a bit about it. Frodo Baggins, a hobbit, receives a magic ring from his uncle Bilbo but according to the wizard Gandalf's researches, the ring is cursed, because the Dark Lord has put in it a piece of his black evil soul and everyone who keeps the One Ring will have a corrupted soul for ever. So Frodo has to travel with his friend Samvise Gamgee and his cousins Meriadoc Brandibuck and Peregrin Tuc. When they get to Elrond the elf's home and after a very long meeting, Elrond decides to make a Fellowship of heroes from different free Middle Earth's races: Frodo, Sam, Merry and Pipin for Hobbits, Legolas Leafgreen for Elves, Aragorn II son of Arathorn, Gondor heir and Boromir son of Denethor for Men, Gimli son of Gloin for Dwarves and Gandalf as a guide. The fellowship has to get to Mordor and destroy the One ring in the only way it can be destroyed: by throwing it in the Mount Doom, a giant volcano in the land of Mordor where the shadows lie. But during the journey Saruman the white, an evil-becomed wizard, attacks the Fellowship. At the end Sam and Frodo decide to leave the Fellowship and continue their mission alone, Aragorn, Legolas and Gimli decide to hunt some orchs who had kidnapped Merry and Pipin. Gandalf has died during a fight. As I've seen the extra contents of my extended edition blu-ray box, I can definetly say that we're talking about a technical masterpiece, but I have to complain about the screenplay: I know that Peter Jackson has made a 1200 pages book into a 150 pages scrrenplay, but in the novel there is an episode (the Hobbits meet Tom Bombadil) that isn't even mentioned in the movie, neither in the "normal" edition nor in the extended one. Anyway, even if Christopher Tolkien (J. R. R. Tolkien's last living son) is against Peter Jackson's work, I strongly disagree, because this big troupe has worked a lot and has spent bilions of dollars to make this movies and I think that this Fellowship of the Ring is the best Tolkien adjustements that could have been made. 4 and a half stars completely deserved.

The reason why this first part of Jackson's 'Lord of the Rings' is superior to his latter two parts is because of restraint. Jackson was restrained from over doing it with the CGI and "epic" battle sequences, which in my opinion does not make a story epic. Part of the reason was simply because Tolkien did not have very many battles in the first part of his book, which thankfully forced Jackson to focus on creating a believable world rather than a believable hack-n-slash action movie.

I don't find much entertainment in watching people mutilate each other, but I love it when a movie engages me in a world, and 'The Fellowship of the Ring' does just that. Certainly the most breathtaking scenes in the movie are the moments of patient observation, when the camera pans around and captures the beautiful settings of Middle Earth. I must give Jackson credit. He did hire some very extraordinary artists that have envisioned one of the grandest interpretations of Tolkien's world.

There are about five particular moments that stick out in my mind and gave me that tingle of goosebumps down my spine when I saw them for the first time. The first is the introduction to Hobbiton. After the somewhat awkward prologue, I was beginning to have my doubts to whether the movie would live up to the book. But the movie surprised me. Hobbiton is perfect. The houses have flower patches and old fences, the roads look worn and made through decades of travel, and the Old Mill spins with the laziness of a quiet town. Every color is vibrant and every moment looks as through it was taken out of a picture book. Although I still don't agree with the particular look of the Hobbits, I believe everything else in Hobbiton is worthy of Tolkien's words.

The second moment comes after Frodo's awakening in Rivendell, and the third, during the exploration of the Halls of Moria. In both moments, the camera pans away from the characters and outward into a static shot of their surroundings. The moments make us feel like we're turning our heads and gazing at the world around us just as the characters do. The golden waterfalls of the elven city mark an interesting contrast with the dark halls of the dwarfish mines, but each are inspiring in their own ways and add to feeling of being engaged in a living world.

My other favorite moments come during the exploration of Lothlorien and the passage down the Anduin. And while I won't go into detail about the scenes, since they really should be experienced without any prior expectations, they are monuments in imaginative cinema. 'The Fellowship of the Ring' is one of those rare movies that I always wish I could reexperience for the first time. Unfortunately, Jackson turned away from exploring Middle Earth in his next two movies, and instead, turned to fighting and warfare. He seems to take a lot of pride in the love story and battle sequences he created in 'The Two Towers' and 'The Return of the King,' but it is was in his first movie when he really got it right. In 'The Fellowship of the Ring,' it's okay if the characters are uninteresting and have silly dialogue. Middle Earth is the star, and the characters are the ones seeing it for the first time.

..but oh was I thankful for it!!! All through the movie I kept on having this big large smile sculpted into my face. For the record, I'm 25 years old, and I've read "The Lord of the Rings" in three times for the first time when I was six or seven years old. Ever since then, I read it at least once or twice a year - therefore you can count me as a fan, for I follow the same cult fan procedure with "The Hobbit" and "The Silmarillion" as well. Now onto the movie... Gosh, I saw it more than one time, and I keep wanting more of it. It just never gets boring! I really enjoyed the little stuff that is found throughout the movie for fans of the books (the map on Bilbo's table in his house comes to mind, it is exactly as the one in "The Hobbit" book that I own), and I also incredibly enjoyed the intro sequence with the re-telling of the battle against Sauron from the Silmarillion, never has an ultimate evil being been so well depicted on the screen. It truly is Sauron.

Those who argue the movie cuts too many parts or that it changes the story too much are totally wrong. This movie could not have shown the whole first time in its entirety - keep in mind that the audiobook version of 'Fellowship of the Ring' lasts well over ten hours, making a movie this long would, well, make it way too long and besides, how would you financially sustain such a project? I've read a reviewer saying he'd make all three books with the time allowed for the first movie alone. I think it would be a very fast-forwarding experience of a movie with 'Alvin and the Chimpmunks' kind of voices, incredibly stupid to say the least.

Ok, so there are changes in the movie - well, this is Jackson's vision of it. All of us have our own visions of the books, which may or may not be compatible with that of Jackson's, but I can safely assume that nobody can say they have a hundred percent the same vision of the story as Tolkien; that's the thing with books: each reader has a different vision of it. As for me, I was blown away. Never before have I felt so much at home in a movie, it is as if I had taken a walk in the town where I grew up, the Shire, Rivendell, Moria, Lorien, everything felt so much like home, I was moved. I cannot tell of another movie that had me shed tears just by seeing a landscape on screen.

As for the changes, well, I found good reasons behind all of them, and let me tell you right away, I was happy that Arwen saved Frodo, yes, maybe coming from a fan it will look like absolute heresy, but I enjoyed the scene a lot. I did not enjoy it because it was supposedly politically-correct to do so, or that I find Liv Tyler to be absolutely attractive; it was just because I felt like even though it was a big change from the book, it was a very good one indeed, it makes you discover the power, determination, and courage of elves and the fact that even elven women, although great in their beauty and seemingly fragile in appearance do not have anything to envy to their male counterparts. And beside, as Arwen is to become a Queen later on, it was pretty good to see her have a great first appearance.

The actors were great, they were a lot into their characters, and for the first time, I saw elves as they were, quick, agile, terrifyingly effective in battle - just look at how Legolas dealed with the hordes of enemies without a single hint of fear in his eyes - these are elves as they should be. Gimli was great too, I know people seem to think many characters were not developed enough, but by the actions you can learn a lot. With Gimli a lot can be learned about the dwarves, their pride, deep sense of honor and family, their mistrust of elves, their love for strong beer and a good fight against anything bigger, and their sheer hatred for orcs and the likes. Aragorn was totally the ranger character, the ending scene as he walked toward the horde of Uruk-Hai warriors was great, his attitude, his clothes, everything about him just cried "ranger". Boromir was very well depicted, desperate to save the people of Gondor, by any mean necessary, robbed of all hope, yet in the end he redeems himself by showing his true valour, deep down, he's willing to die to defeat evil, and when he recognizes his king in Aragorn, on his last breath, I felt like watching a hero die, it was moving. The hobbits were all great, Frodo is deeply sad and fatalist, and Sam is just the 'best friend' everyone would like to have, just as it should be. Finally, we have Gandalf, quite frankly, he looks mighty, Ian IS Gandalf. The faceoff against the Balrog in the Moria is a memorable sequence, and just shows how strong he really is, to be able to vanquish such a foe. I can't wait for his return.

Quite frankly, I can't wait for the two other movies... In the meantime, I'll watch this one over and over again. This movie has everything that a good movie needs to have, and more. Plus, it just might bring more people to actually read books that have more pages than the average little 25¢ novel that has no value in it, which is great. Parents, maybe some scenes will frighten your kids, but this movie has almost NO blood (even though it has a good share of battle) and the foes are undeniably evil, plus it has good values in it - friendship, courage, responsiblity, sacrifice for a good cause, and the belief that anyone can help to change things. This is worthy of Tolkien, this is a movie that will go down in history as being one of the best ever, for sure.

"The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring" released in 2001, is the beginning of the story of Frodo and his journey to destroy the ring of power that threatens Middle Earth. The movie makes me feel hopeful. As many moments as there were where the characters experience a lapse of judgment, such as Boromir coming after Frodo and trying to steal the ring just before the battle with the Orcs, Boromir proceeds to redeem himself by sacrificing his life for Merry and Pippin's, as well as declaring his loyalty to Aragorn as his king and their homeland of Gondor.

The movie made me think about how relatable these events and reactions are, as well as how there's a recurring theme between this movie and others like it. In one of the Harry Potter movies (I can't remember which one) Dumbledore says, "We must choose between what is easy and what is right." I feel that the altercation between Frodo and Boromir is an example of that. One thing I found to be particularly interesting was that the ring wraiths seem to fear the elements. This is shown when Aragorn fights them off with fire, and when Arwen sends the rushing water after them after she rescues Frodo to bring him to Rivendell for her father Elrond to save him.

I would have liked to see the special effects done differently. Specifically in the prologue scenes, there were moments where the effects stood out and didn't exactly feel to have cohesiveness within the scenes. I also would have liked to see slower dolly shots. Specifically in the scene where Gandalf and Frodo are talking about the ring and its powers, there were quite a few slow dolly shots used for suspense and reaction. I feel that they would have created even more suspense and a stronger reaction if they were slowed down even more, though maybe that's just the style that I'm used to seeing in films made for today's audience.

It is a joy to see a story you love brought to big screen in such a faithful and carefully made adaptation. The Lord of the Rings trilogy is clearly a labour of love for Peter Jackson and everyone involved in this film from the acting, costumes, props, music, cgi and beyond. The film is able to take the most important parts of the novel and create Middle Earth on screen in a very believable manner, using the different languages from the books such as the Elvish languages and Black Speech and the landscapes and structures depicted by Alan Lee and John Howe. With such a big cast it's also an achievement that every main character is so well performed, fleshed out and memorable, with Elijah Wood, Ian Mckellen, Sean Bean and Viggo Mortensen's giving particularly great performances. This film has something for everyone whether you are a fan of the books or not, with a mixture of action, romance, humour and high fantasy that is a great introduction to the trilogy and builds excitement for the next film.

You are immediately introduced to this stunning, fantasy world, which has been directed so well and cinematographed ingeniously, that you never want to leave it. The very talented cast definitely add that great sense of realism to the world, appearing ultimately convincing in their roles they play so ingeniously. The special effects were done strikingly well, with the monsters looking life like, especially because of the crisp direction. The action in this film knows where it needs to be to fit in with the captivating drama, and finally, despite this being a very long film, and being a very good film - I'd usually say this almost four hour film flew by in a breeze, but I could acknowledge that this film was four hours long and it felt four hours long to me, but I didn't want it to end. I give this film a 10/10.

Peter jackson harnesses tolkien's golden horse of a novel into cinematic formating that will prove to be both promising and unpromising in comparison with its genre.New line cinema's herioc high end fantasy adventure "fellowship of the Ring" stars an ensemble of renowned actors,such as,Ian mckellen's impeccable performance as the Wise Wizard Gandalf,Orlando Bloom and Viggo Mortensen stern portrayals of legalos and aragorn,but lets not forget billy boyd,Sean Astin,Dominic Monoghan,and Elijah Wood who respectfully interpret their hafling companions as Pippin,Sam,Merry,and Frodo baggins.Although Peter jackson implements the Archetype repesentation of the interpersonal conflict between the good and evil of middle earth,readers such as myself will look down at their empty plates and realize that their is still much that needs to be explored and indulged in.The films narrative demonstartes a sizable amount of loyality and respect for the book but its frenetic pacing is an encroaching disease that is prevelant throughout the movie.This bold risk in pacing will leave a prolific amount of enthralling chapters absent from the film,consistently the story will jump from a "short cut to mushrooms" to "At The sign of a prancing pony",without care of aknowledging some of the most exciting and fear inducing chapters of the book,being the trecherous area's of "the old forest","In The House of Tom Bombadil",and "Fog on the Barrow-Downs".All these chapters strongly personify our characters plight and also inject pathos in our beloved protagonists.Though the plot will seem prematurley developed with its gapping plotholes and abridged scenes,it still manages to make a miraculous recovery in the most serene ways possible.What jackson's film lacks he remedies with the most cavernous mise-en-scenes of science fiction.His vast tranquil and perilous enviornmental settings are also a true testament to the dynamic of his  aerial cinematography.This use of camera framing blends innately with harsh settings such as the snowy caradhras and the golden woods.In conclusion jackson's three hours and forty eights minute time duration still leaves much to be desired with its bittersweet conclusion but still serves as a commendable strong visual and sound medium that will continue to be a contemporary with the block buster Star Wars.
