[Warning! This review may contain spoilers about the book and not the movie in order to give a fair review the book has to be mentioned.]

The movie was overall enjoyable with some clear great points and fails. To begin the positives of the move were not few which is a good thing in its own right but onto what those positives are. First was the fitting music and how it enhanced the experience of every scene it was placed in. Second is the CGI effects and how it really added to the depth of the story because of how well done the effects were. The final positive is that the camera angels and lighting where spot on for every scene. Now onto the negatives, to start the filmmakers decided to leave out the character of Tom Bombadil form the text. This being a negative in two ways the first being that film makers do not show that there is a living being alive that is able to overcome the rings power. The second is that the entire forest journey was cut out and that part of the story was so pose to set in the fear of being far away from home in the hobbits. The second negative is that the filmmakers overextended the love story of Aragorn/Strider and Arwen when it was only insinuated in the novel. The final negative is that when Frodo leaves the Fellowship his companions let him go instead of trying to find him and stop him like in the text. So, overall the movie was quite enjoyable but should be taken with a grain of salt as there are many inaccuracies in this film, but even so this gets a sold 3.5-4/5 stars from me.

The Fellowship of the Ring was great for the time with amazing effects and keeping to the majority of the original plot of the book by J.R.R. Tolkien. However, with some character switches and the simplification of plot points and characters it blurs the overall message Tolkien tried to portray as a war narrative. Overall, it did the best it could with transitioning the mediums of the story and is worth the four hours in front of your TV.

Despite the compelling performance by the cast and the great film crew, the portrayal of the Fellowship of the Rings, in my opinion, was not too great. The story is a classic, which may be why this, the first of the trilogy, was so much more successful than most other films in its position. Even as this being so I did not find the movie all that great. I found it to be not as similar to the book as I would have hoped it would be. It excluded some important scenes and also included unnecessary romances and scenes. The special effects of the movie were well done in my opinion, the scenes were well depicted and most of the time very accurate. Despite the high stakes of being killed at any moments by anything evil the script keeps the humor and excitement alive in every scene. The background music and sound effects really brought the movie to life and made sure there wasn't a boring moment in the movie. All of the acting was spectacular and the actors really were able to become the character. I would recommend the movie to anyone who likes fantasy action or The Lord of the Rings books. It is very serious, so don't watch it with a big group unless that group is interested in the movie instead of socializing. The movie is extremely long, so if you refuse to dedicate three hours in any variations of division to one movie, watch the cartoon version. Overall Rating: 2.5

I could start off by claiming that all the characters in the Lord of the Rings are two-dimensional, with little depth, and hardly any character development. I could state how there is nothing interesting about some characters in the universe and they are all black and white with some having little to no motive. I could say that it's foolish to focus so much on the creation of orcs just for them to die an hour later in the film. But it's simply not the truth. Now let me begin by saying I truly love the Lord of the Rings films. I do. However, a particular problem within the trilogy is a lack in development of a large amount of characters.  Specifically within The Fellowship of the Ring I'm here to talk about one of the movies biggest flaws. With the lack of development of character in the films, one of the biggest crimes was killing off one of the most full-fledged characters in the first movie, Boromir. Why was it essential to kill this character fairly early on within the lore? What purpose does it serve to the story and overall arc? Why focus on the development of his character to kill him off so early on?

	Boromir was something of an exception to the Lord of the Rings trilogy. In a universe where every character is regarded as good or evil, Boromir is one of the few in the gray area. His character is neither good or bad. His character has depth to it, it has struggles like the everyday man does. He is a good man who is struggling with the weight of his legacy within the fellowship. The ring sees this and prays upon it to tempt his will. It's something that makes him a 3-dimensional character, and one of the very first in the overall story. Though he was willing to do evil to get the ring, the ring was tempting him with a good purpose, to save his people. There are few people in The Lord of the Rings trilogy who experience the same kind of character exploration throughout their time on screen, needless to say how short his was. This is what makes Boromir such a greatly developed character, which is why it's bitter-sweet when his character meets an end.

	His death is especially criminal to the character in general. As in the books Boromir's death occurs within "The Two Towers" rather than "The Fellowship of the Ring". Had they kept it true to the original text they could have interpreted more in the second movie, rather than spending a large portion of it waiting for the Ent's to decide if they would help the twins or not. There would have been more content within the storyline, and it would have kept a great character rolling throughout more than just one hour within the entirety of the films. This could have made him more of a key character. However, they decided to cut his character short and leave us departed from a great character sooner than what was necessary.

	So what's the point of all of this, you might ask. As great a character as Boromir is, the flaw within the story is that his character is only within the story for a mere hour. And over this hour, this one character had more of a story to him than other characters such as Legolas and Gimli, who had been covered for 3 movies. In fact Legolas only had 37 lines throughout all three of the films, only one of these lines was said to Frodo. Yes, Boromir seems like a minor role when compared to others, however, the fact that we got to see all sides to Boromir within his struggle, and only seemingly generic stories, in comparison, from other characters who were panned through all 3 films, speaks for itself.

The lacking choice of character development, and where, is one of the trilogy's major flaws. Leaving your characters who were maintained through a larger amount of time underdeveloped and exploring characters who have minimal screen time is not ideal for the development of roles throughout the films. Underdevelopment in lengthier characters is a poor choice, especially when the time used on Boromir could have been used to expand on a larger character, maybe such as the twins, or even Frodo a bit more, learn more about Sarumon and his motives, etc. The character of Boromir should have been extended into the second film for the use of further content, which would also help extend the point of him being as developed as he was, and driving the plot to be more correct to the original lore.

To me this movie is the best movie of all time. Why you might ask. Well let me tell you why. First off it's music and score is flawless. It even won a handful of Grammys. Cinematography is also flawless. It looks absolutely stunning and gorgeous and was actually filmed and shot in New Zealand so it's not all just CGI like everything nowadays. 

Acting is amazing. Okay the acting may not be Oscar worthy but it's not because the acting is bad it's because Oscar worthy acting is not required in this type of film. The plot is very interesting and original and is also not a generic, boring and lame plot like we see rehashed in all the movies nowadays. The setting is beautiful and intriguing and has its own world called Middle-Earth. 

One of the best things about this movie and series is it has its own world and culture. Every character, villain, enemy, language, culture, and race has its own unique background and origin created by Tolkien in his book. For instance, Legolas and the elves have their own language and lifestyle they live by. So do the Hobbits, Men, and Dwarves. Except not all of them have their own language but they do all have their own lifestyle. 

The theme is a very inspiring theme. "What is the theme" you might ask. Well it's to fight evil temptations you deal with everyday and to ultimately win the battle with temptation and to always do what is good and right even with all the evil and temptation surrounding you. Lastly, and explaining how this movie could be better than ones like Godfather or Citizen Kane is all three of those are epic, inspiring, well developed, well executed, well acted, well directed, and very popular and beloved. 

But why makes Lord of the Rings better than those? Well first of all it has a better score and probably the best score of all time. Also has better cinematography and design. But it all comes down to Lord of the Rings is just as good movie and critic wise as both of those but manages to be way more entertaining. Honestly it's jut more versatile because it can be just as epic, well acted, and directed but still be one of the most entertaining movies as well.

This is probably the best of the three movies and there are many reasons why. This is the movie that started the entire series and, man, did it do that in the most beautiful way imaginable. This movie introduced us to what we all know now as Middle-earth, the most magical and beautiful place ever seen on the screen. We have an entire fellowship of characters who all have very different personalities, but are able to put aside their differences and work together in order to bring the One Ring into the last place any normal being would ever want to enter. This is a perfect movie in almost every thinkable way.

This movie excels in being a fantasy masterpiece, the story is amazing, the only downside would be the run-time, as the movie gets boring some times, but it manages to keep your attention for almost the entire movie.

The Fellowship Of The Ring had a lot to live up to. One of the greatest works of fiction of all time, The Lord Of The Rings novels by J..R.R. Tolkein, is considered a popular classic with a tremendously loyal and well read fan base. Tolkein's attention to detail and genius in creating an entire new world, Middle Earth, complete with its own languages, has such a high standard that it has plagued earlier attempts to retell the story. 

This film delivers and not only respects most of the source material, but is successful at unfolding a complex story arc in a believable and digestible manner for mass consumption audiences. Kudos to Peter Jackson for pulling this off given the herculean task of tackling this high fantasy epic of literature.

As a devoted reader of the Tolkein books, I was completely satisfied with this portrayal on film.

With excellent acting, a fascinating  plot, a beautiful soundtrack, and stunning visuals, there is literally no reason a person should not watch "The Lord of the Rings". From start to finish you will be mesmerized by the emotional story of a young hobbit on a perilous journey to destroy "the one ring of power". While watching this magnificent movie you will be immersed into it and lose all awareness of the things going on around you. Make sure to use the bathroom and grab all of your snacks before you start this epic because you aren't going to want to miss a second of it.

The Fellowship of the Ring sets a high bar as the first installment in Peter Jackson's 3-film masterpiece. 

From the opening sequence, this film does a near-flawless job of dropping the audience into JRR Tolkien's Middle Earth. The film is long and the least exciting of the trilogy, but it still must be commended for expertly introducing and developing numerous heroes and villains. The sweeping landscapes and excellent writing transports us to a world that feels mesmerizing and familiar, all at the same time. 

The Fellowship Ring may not be the best of the Lord of the Rings trilogy, but it sure isn't far off.

Tolkien's Literary Classic Comes to Life on the Big Screen!

Originally Written December 19, 2001--
The future of civilization rests in the fate of the One Ring, which has been lost for centuries. Powerful forces are unrelenting in their search for it. But fate has placed it in the hands of a young Hobbit named Frodo Baggins (Elijah Wood), who inherits the Ring and steps into legend. A daunting task lies ahead for Frodo when he becomes the Ringbearer - to destroy the One Ring in the fires of Mount Doom where it was forged.

I have been a huge fan of 'The Lord of the Rings' since I first read Tolkien's masterpiece in Middle School. I was so disappointed in Hollywood's first attempt to bring this classic story to the big screen---a regrettable 1978 animated version. I was absolutely thrilled to see that a live-action version was being planned for this year. But I was shocked to see how amazing Peter Jackson's version truly is! I loved this first chapter in the story of Frodo and the Fellowship of the Ring begin their journey to Mordor! And the cliffhanger ending at the end of Part 1 is fantastic! I can't wait for Part 2! Five stars.

A wonderful start to a fantastic trilogy. While "The Hobbit" movies technically make this the fourth in the series, "The Lord of the Rings" will always be a separate trilogy to me. There are great characters, amazing special effects that hold up to this day, and Peter Jackson's respect for the source material is astounding. The only problem I have is that the movie can get very dark. Like, so dark I have to up the brightness on my TV to even see what's going on. Other than that though, this is an absolute winner.
Peter Jackson kicks of the Lord of the rings trilogy in style, immersing the viewer in the world of hobbits, orcs, goblins, wizards, warriors and other creatures
Awesome actions and graphics, and a great story.

The movie, Lord of the Rings by J.R.R Tolkien, was an exciting film that gave an entertaining perspective of a war narrative. This book entertained viewers through the the journey that accompanied creatures with a great burden. It proposed the idea of the underdog in the way that an unlikely character would become a hero. It deals with struggles relatable in the lives of everyday people even though these emotions are being expressed by characters that are far from ordinary. Its an emotional journey that tests the strength of all those who choose to undertake the journey. It took a toll on the emotions of the viewers and was far from predictable. I would highly recommend this movie to any and all who love a good underdog story!!

I thought the movie was amazing. It had cool graphics, awesome characters and cast and immersed me into an old, rustic world. Jackson had created an amazing visual representation of the book and even added some of his own twists. Even though he took some characters and important points of the plot he really followed the book and kept mostly everything as Tolkein described it. Overall, it is an amazing film and I recommend watching it.

The Fellowship of the Ring was an overall great movie. It had closely followed the book but it had also either gained or lost some scenes. For example the exclusion of Tom Bombadil and the love story between Aragorn and Arwen. This may have made many people curious as to why the director did this and I know I am very curious about this myself. Each scene was portrayed well and the plot had been well thought out and seemed to flow easily. The director Peter Jackson had done a great job with the setting and mood of most of the scenes. So overall I believe that Peter did an excellent job of portraying J.R.R. Tolkien's book as best as it could be.

This was honestly a great visual representation of the original text by J. R. R. Tolkien. The visual effects made the movie look like something that actually happened. Although some elements weren't exactly like the text, it was overall a really entertaining movie.

In my opinion, I really enjoyed the movie. I liked how Jackson incorporated The Love Story between Aragorn and Arwen added a nice touch to the movie because everything about the movie is action and fantasy. Another thing that I thought that Jackson did a good job was on the film techniques. His camera angles and zooms captured the right tone. He also did a good job picking the characters roles. When I read the book, I expected Gandalf and Frodo to look how they did in the film.

The fellowship of the ring is a great book turned into an even better movie. Although they leave out a few parts from the book, it still has good characters and a truly immersive story. Worth the two hours for this big-budget action, adventure, fantasy movie.

This movie was a great movie, it added action pack scenes, drama, and a lot of great other qualities too ,but if you are a big fan of the book this is gonna break your heart because it wasn't even close to it. They took out a lot of scenes and added some that weren't even useful to the plot line but a good movie if you haven't read the book.

This film captured main plot points from the novel and displayed them at a good pace without scenes dragging out more than they should have. It is a great way of understanding the novel. Has incredible scenery that is only found in dreams. The film did lack some plot points but overall great film!

This movie, although it had its rough parts, matched a good portion of the official storyline in the book.  A few of the similarities would be for example the Ring Wraiths and that they were accurately described as in the book, and the Hobbits in the Shire were depicted the same as in the book.  Although it had its similarities, the movie also added a few scenes that never happened in the book along with skipping large amounts of time that passed in the book, both of which are understandable as the producers were only trying to increase entertainment values.  Overall, this was a great movie, but I would only rate four stars due to the fact that it changed too many key factors from the book.

The movie has its pros and cons. It excludes characters and scenes from the book that weren't terribly important. The film simplifies many things, and contains more action than the book. The characters are interesting and come to life in the film in ways they didn't in the text. Some things are changed, but the major events are the same.

The Lord of the Rings was an interesting movie, and had high entertainment value. The story line was fast paced and developed well. There were a lot of high action scenes and excitement in the movie. There was also a good amount of emotion, such as when Bilbo had to leave Frodo at Bag End. There was also a good amount of humor. The special effects were also surprisingly impressive. Overall, this was a good movie and I enjoyed watching it.

This movie was an interesting movie.  Peter Jackson I believe did a decent job on showing is visualization of the book in this movie.  For the most part, the movie was similar to the book but some things made my opinion of the movie go down.  Like how Peter Jackson gave Arwen a very large speaking role when she did not speak even one word in the book and also how he gave Arwen and Aragorn a major love story but in the book it is only hinted at that Aragorn liked Arwen.  Peter Jackson also did not include Tom Bombadil in the movie but he had an important role in the book.  Some of the parts I like in the movie was Peter Jackson's representation of the confrontation between Gandalf and the Balrog.  This part of the movie was almost exactly like the book, if not better.  I also liked how Peter Jackson kept the same nine characters for the fellowship and how he kept the same path that the fellowship took in the book.  Overall I enjoyed the movie but I wish Peter Jackson added in those missing parts, that would have sold the movie even more to me.

It doesn't get better than this (oh, wait! it does, The Return of the King is even better!). Excellent acting, incredible direction, great script and some really good music merge into a masterpiece that's not to be forgotten.

This movie, like any other, had its ups and downs. One of the things I personally thought mirrored the book was the portrayal of the Balrog and the battle between it and Gandalf a little later on. However, there were also things that weren't in line with the book, Like Arwen having a speaking role while in the book she never spoke a single word. A lot of the parts were very similar to the book and it was not hard to understand what was happening. However it was those moments where it drastically strayed from the book that killed it for me.

The Lord of The Rings: The Fellowship of The Ring is a really good movie. If you read the book and went to the movie, people might disagree. It contains all of the important ideas that the books has but, it displays them with different details. Peter Jackson did a great job of analyzing the book and making it to a movie. Just a few minor errors that he could of fix. The big one is making Arwen  a big character. Overall, The Fellowship of The Ring was a good movie.

I love fantasy and science fiction, but even moreso when a film does the original source material justice, while standing on its own merits as a cinematic production.

Peter Jackson's epic trilogy is one such trilogy I feel are films you have to see, regardless if you're into fantasy or science fiction or not.  

The first part of the trilogy remains a cinematic triumph in my eyes, full of amazing special effects, expert cinematography, pacing, and excellent acting.

While people before attempted to translate Tolkien's groundbreaking epic to film, few have done it with elegance, class, action, and imagination of Peter Jackson's take on the series.

While the film is incredibly faithful, it isn't a perfect transliteration.  And mostly I'm fine with that, as the first film is as faithful as you can hope to get, and the way the film brings Tolkien's vision to the screen could have been narmy, but luckily it provided us with a faithful and imaginative take on the work.

My overall favorite scene in the film is Aragorn's fight with Lurtz, which never happened in the original novel, and I'm saddened by that, as it contains some of the best choreography and has an epic feel to it that I feel it should have been in the original novel.

It's little diversions like this that make the film faithful but incredibly imaginative.

Overall, this film gets a 9/10 on my scale.  While it's an achievement of cinematography, acting, and production, it  isn't perfect due to entirely reasonable diversions due to the praticality of producing a film with such a large budget.
You get to know the characters and there is a more simple plot, something the hobbit didn't have.
The one that started them all! One of the greatest films of all time!

As a huge fan of Tolkien's work, I didn't think his fantasy epic was filmable. I didn't particularly look forward to seeing this film when it opened, and was dragged to the theater by my coworkers one night after our shift. I stood corrected. Peter Jackson's trilogy was perfectly cast and did justice to the books. The mix of practical effects and CGI was almost seamless. I was especially impressed with how wonderfully the filmmakers brought the Shire, the Mines of Moria, the ringwraiths, the Balrog, to life that so closely matched the way I pictured them when I read the book--it was almost like telepathy. This is a triumph of special effects, storytelling and modern filmmaking.
Absolutely enjoyable, beautifully shot, awesome performances, perfect casting, but not perfect. Of course, this was the huge build up to what was to come, but that doesn't make it bad in any way.

Such a shame as I enjoyed listening to it, when read by my school teacher at the age of 9. It's only redeeming feature in my opinion is the special effects, which are in truth very good, but this is lost on you, due to the frustration of wanting to see some action. Boring.

High fantasy quite often when done in film just comes off as epic, and this little gem is no exception. I really shouldn't have used the word little because this is the complete opposite, the scale is huge, the adventure is huge and to be fair some of the creatures in this are huge. Fellowship of the Ring is of course based on the work of J. R. R Tolkien of the same named book and is one movie that is quite obviously popular among those who have read the book, adding to the fact this film is obviously fantastic. I don't feel this is quite absolute perfection but in any case it is a sublime piece of work and one that few would doubt is one of the very best still in the fantasy genre of films.

Peter Jackson brings us his view on this quest and he does a fine fine job with guiding us through this story with a scope never seen before this came out. The thing about this that I feel captures so many peoples interest is the way in which it is just genuinely good fun and never goes too dark or too serious, it has moments of light hearted fun and even the odd time when you get a laugh out, splendid stuff. Jackson alongside Philippa Boyens and Fran Walsh adapts a script that breathes what a movie like this should be done like, it gets the very most out of the action done in it and blends with the effects in a way where you don't get sick of the CGI or feel this is too fake, it turns out beautiful. The look this movie is given is also one major thing to mention about this just in the way the sets and the locations and even the costumes are done, it vividly brings to life Middle-earth in a way where it doesn't matter if you have read the books beforehand or after or ever, the movie is itself a work of epic proportions.

Frodo Baggins is of course the central character of this and being played by Elijah Wood he comes across as brave in ways but also at times very vulnerable as well. If there is one stand out performance, well I wouldn't be able to pick, all the huge cast do a top notch job of bringing their respective characters to life and create these roles which they will forever be known for. One thing about casting I also really liked is the way in which the people behind this didn't go for massive names or try to even draw maybe just one massive name that would have ruined this, it feels better with a varied cast popularity wise.

This has one of the most engaging second halves I have seen and moves this movie up a little in terms of how I felt about it overall. The film I think also sets up the next two in the series really well, it shows us what might come next although never too much and that for me makes this a great link going into "The Two Towers". Peter Jackson a fan of the Tolkien's work brilliantly brings this storming onto the big screen and does so in a way that makes it very difficult to dislike, even those with an ardent dislike for the kind words used in this like Khazad-dûm will find it hard to not enjoy this movie, it is just too much fun and too much an epic movie. So yes overall The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring is one movie that will go down in history as a game changer in terms of technical achievements and truly brought on a new era of usage regarding CGI. It goes down in many lists as one of the bests and although I can't say I felt this to be your 5 star, 10/10 kind of movie, it is still terrific in almost every single way.

The first in a trilogy of movies that become better and better, this movie was to my generation what Star Wars was to my parents: a movie that appeared on the eve of a dreadfully boring period of movies and then captured hearts and minds forever with its characters, scenery, stirring score, and timeless storytelling.  This is where your journey down Middle-Earth begins, and after which you will never be the same again.

Spectacular epic beginning of the most successful trilogy in film history. Elijah Wood shines as Frodo Baggins, the hobbit who bears the fate of Middle Earth within his hand, the One Ring which could bring disaster to the world. Sean Astin is perfect as Frodo's loyal gardener and friend, Sam Gamgee. Ian McKellen does an astounding Oscar-nominated performance as the great and wise wizard Gandalf the Grey. The casting for the film was perfect and WETA Workshop did an astounding with the costumes, the visual effects, and the overall production design of the film and it's sequels. Gloriously epic Oscar-winning music from Howard Shore, who's music sends us to a world we only dreamed of reading JRR Tolkien's books. From the peaceful music of the Shire to the epic score within the dark corridors of Moria, the music never ceases to amaze me in it's grand scale. One of the best films of all-time.

The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) C-178m. ??? D: Peter Jackson. Elijah Wood, Ian McKellen, Sean Astin, Orlando Bloom, Viggo Mortensen, Ian Holm, Cate Blanchett, Sean Bean. A young hobbit and eight other formidable companions set out on a journey to destroy a powerful ring, which if fallen into the wrong hands could release the Dark Lord Sauron. A most visionary achievement from British film director Jackson with impeccable style and intense vigorousness to match his most frenzied works. Film moves in fit and starts, and lacks the impact of the latter entries, but it pays back in spades; it's still impressive, with near-perfect casting (McKellen is magnificent), spectacular special effects, and overall formidable production. Academy Award winner for Andrew Lesnie's Cinematography and Howard Shore's soaring music. Extended Edition runs 208m. Followed by THE LORD OF THE RINGS: THE TWO TOWERS.

When I was seven years old, my dad decided to begin reading a book to my sister and I. It was a big book and we didn't expect to be finishing it anytime soon, but my dad persevered and continued reading night after night, chapter after chapter. The creatures and characters which were conjured up in my mind as my dad read The Fellowship of the Ring, complete with voices and gestures, will remain with me forever. 

This is the challenge Peter Jackson was left with in creating the first in his Lord of the Rings trilogy: the collective imagination of literally millions of fans, each one filled with different intricacies and opinions concerning characters, settings, basically everything involved in production design and being a director in general. With such a burden weighing on Jackson's shoulders, no one would have blamed him if he simply curled into the foetal position and sobbed when he actually bagged the role of director. But I'm sure I speak for fans, critics and the entire world when I say that I'm so glad that he didn't. 

The first in the sweeping epic of the Lord of the Rings, The Fellowship of the Ring begins with the origin of the one ring; an object created by the dark lord Sauron in order to take over Middle Earth. After a battle sequence or two, we join up with our hero of the piece; Frodo Baggins, a Hobbit from the Shire. After finding out that his Uncle Bilbo's magic ring is in fact the ring in question, Frodo is forced to undertake a journey to Mordor in order to destroy the ring once and for all. A fellowship of nine warriors is formed in order to help Frodo on his journey and the quest begins. 

Even the synopsis above comes laden with backstory and explanation. What is a Hobbit? What is a Sauron? What is a Frodo? All these questions can mean that the film can become bogged down with explaining what the exact properties of Hobbit's feet are that they are able to never wear shoes or how exactly the Ringwraiths are able to survive at all. It is a credit to the script that none of this is explained, nor does it feel necessary to be explained. Even for a newcomer to Middle Earth, the escapist factor of the world onscreen is enough to dismiss any disbelief or need to find out how exactly shadow and flame combine to be a Balrog. Not only this, but the script also does a fantastic job of cutting out everything unnecessary in order to keep the storytelling lean. It also manages, while trimming the extra weight (in the form of things like Tom Bombadil), to keep the feeling of wonder that the books are so renknowned for. Many book adaptations can end up being driven by the story alone, allowing no time for the more emotional moments between characters and forgetting entirely to establish connections between them. Not so here, as every member of the fellowship is allowed their moment on the screen, from Boromir to Gimli, and all of them have their own distinct personality. 

This personality distinction can also be attributed to the perfectly cast ensemble. Every single character has their perfect corresponding actor to play their onscreen counterpart. J.R.R Tolkien, the books' author, actually endorsed Christopher Lee to be Gandalf (the two were good friends up until Tolkien's death), but despite this glowing reference, Ian McKellen was cast instead, Christopher Lee playing the part of Saruman. Looking at the finished product it's impossible to imagine the roles being reversed as the two are so perfect for their respective parts. The actors themselves do brilliantly. Viggo Mortensen is almost Eastwood-like in his understated effiency as Aragorn, John Rhys-Davies and Orlando Bloom make up one of the great double-acts of the pieces, the other being the hilarious Dominic Monaghan and Billy Boyd as Merry and Pippin. In this we even get to see a little more range from Elijah Wood which is not as evident in the sequels, mainly due to his character's role later on. The standouts, despite the entire ensemble performing fantastically, are Sean Bean as Boromir who displays more talent than National Treasure would give him credit for and Ian McKellen as Gandalf. His performance is the rock that the film can stand on and he seems as though he's not so much visiting Middle Earth as he's been living there his whole life. The gravitas he holds and the empathy he evokes is simply astounding and it's not until repeat viewings that this can really be seen. 

After having made limited successes like Heavenly Creatures and The Frighteners, Peter Jackson stepped up to the plate in a major way in directing the Fellowship of the Ring. As mentioned before, the strain could easily have proved too much but from the very first scene it's obvious that Jackson is more than adept at handling a sweeping epic such as this. As he deftly move through the opening battle sequences and into the beauty and serenity of Hobbiton, Jackson's camera is rarely still, sweeping through the incredible locations and swirling around his characters in a beautifully choreographed dance. Every single shot counts for something and the bare minimum is obviously never enough in Jackson's mind. This is the more beautifully photographed of the three, despite the grandeur and spectacle of the Return of the King. Rohan storming the armies of Mordor is all very well but it's scenes like the Wraiths attacking the four all but helpless Hobbits on Weathertop which leave the most lasting impressions. Jackson's versatility is also on full display here as he moves through the autumn shades of Rivendell to the cold stone of Moria to the eerie blue-green of Lothlorien, every setting is perfectly captured by Jackson's lens. And does he know how to bring the fight scenes. Mr. Bay could take a few pointers in terms of how to shoot a battle scene, whether in the dark of Balin's tomb or the leafy surrounds of Parth Galen, every moment counts and every movement is felt, rather than the mindless slugging out of giant robots. 

The score of Shore also deserves a lot of the credit for fully immersing the audience in the onscreen world. Howard Shore's unmistakable tune is applied liberally throughout the film but it works perfectly every time. The themes and motifs which he includes according to character or even species is astounding. The nostalgia of Hobbiton is beautifully underscored with one of the more subdued peices of the soundtrack but the thundering main theme is as powerful and overwhelming as you would hope it would be and then some. It's no surprise that one of the four Oscars the first film won was for Shore's score (teehee). 

It's the complete immersion in the world of Middle Earth which makes this film so incredible. Despite the film's runtime being close to 3 hours long, even longer in the extended version, it never feels taxing to sit and soak up the breathtaking surrounds. Where some films can feel like a chore at two hours, it's almost impossible to keep from loading the next film instantly after finishing the first one thanks to the incredible power to entrance the film holds. The combination of flawless production design from props to locations along with the beautifully crafted story and faultless direction makes this film one of the greatest of all time. 

Defining Scene: 
The attack on Weathertop. Despite being comprised of far fewer parties than many other battles in the series, the terrifying Ringwraiths more than make up for it.

Review In A Nutshell:

After the bad taste that was The Frighteners, I come back to the series that proved to the world that Peter Jackson is a master of epic filmmaking; rivalling the likes of David Lean, James Cameron, and George Lucas. The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring was released at the time where franchises were at their humble beginnings; standing along with films like X-Men, Harry Potter, and the new Star Wars trilogy. Out of all of them, it was Peter Jackson's film that came out on top, a film that demonstrates the ambition and scope of fantasy with seriousness and visual wonderment.

The film begins by showing the fall of Sauron, an evil figure that has forged the ultimate ring; a ring that possesses such power, feeding the envy and anger of the kingdoms around him. Multiple armies unite to stop him, which they ultimately do, and as Middle-Earth was on the brink of salvation, evil consumed the mind of its holder, extending the life of evil that should have fallen long ago. Then the ring was eventually lost and found by the hands of a simple hobbit; I wouldn't spend too much time discussing this as events that would unfold from here are covered in The Hobbit trilogy and the sequels of this trilogy. The ring acts as a clear symbolism of temptation, how it feasts on our souls, eventually defining our sense of existence. It is a brilliant concept by Tolkien, utilising fantastical elements to capture the imagination of its readers; and to see it translated here under Jackson's direction is simply fantastic.

After recently seeing the final instalment of The Hobbit trilogy, it was a warm feeling to see the next journey unfold; this time carried by the hands and heart of another Hobbit, Frodo Baggins. His adventure here is more serious than the one Bilbo participated, with more at stake for not just the hobbit himself but to everyone around him; and Jackson lets the audience feel this heavy weight on Frodo's shoulders, we completely understand his journey will not be a pleasant one, one that would open his eyes to the beautiful world that surrounds him (which is what Bilbo experienced). Frodo's world is much dimmer, filled with unescapable evil, happiness only found in the deepest depths of Middle-Earth's heart.

Though darker, there are still some beauties to be found in Middle-Earth, and Jackson makes every opportunity to capture it; just take look at the scenes taking place in Rivendell or the helicopter shots of the fellowship running across multiple types of terrain, it is simply gorgeous. Even the darker aspects of the film, may look gritty, but still captures that imaginative beauty that one would now expect from a fantasy film. It manages to capture beauty through natural elements, like mountains and grass, unlike Harry Potter and Star Wars which relies on more artificial elements in order to create that sense of beauty and imagination. There is simply nothing like the imagery of The Lord of the Rings trilogy.

The highlight of the film, of course, is its score. A score so memorable and emotionally touching that it never leaves the inner crevices of our minds. It is epic, standing near atop of the best musical scores every created for cinema. I am currently listening to Howard Shore's score as I am writing this, and I feel a sense of warmth that very few musical compositions could achieve; if only one could see me, they would see the welling of my teary eyes and the goose bumps that fills the surfaces of my flesh.

The cast in this film is amazing, with memorable performances across the board. There was a sense of excitement that filled through me as I saw each character from the fellowship being introduced. They capture their roles with such fun and commitment that it perfectly translates Tolkien's precious characters to life for audiences to take in and adore. Jackson wasn't after a star-studded cast, he was after actors that are a perfect fit for the roles; and neither cast member fails to live up to the expectation of Jackson and his audience.

The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring is a wonderful beginning of a beautiful trilogy; there is simply nothing like it. I cannot wait to continue and revisit the next chapter of the story.
What makes the Lord of the Rings perfect is its amazing cast, spectacular special effects, stunning scenery, and the fact that it sticks to the book like glue.

Ok so I wasn't really in to nor, had any knowledge of 'The Lord Of The Rings' Franchise. Until I saw the first two 'The Hobbit' movies which are prequels. So out of curiousness I bought 'The Lord Of The Rings' Trilogy for Blu-Ray. I never seen the movies but I watch the first movie of the franchise 'The Fellowship Of The Ring' with an open mind. I got to say I enjoyed this movie as much I enjoy 'The Hobbit'. The story element of the plot and backstory is brilliant, original, and effective. I found myself entertained by the most of the film. There were some very slow parts of the movie that bored me and made me uninterested. The use of practical effect and CGI was great collaboration in this film. The sceneries of the movie is very beautiful and well detailed. The movie has extremely likable characters by their courage, personality, and role in the film. For that I like to credit the terrific acting from the whole cast. The actors gave their all in emotional situations and having real chemistry throughout! I had a problem of the dialogue of the film because some parts of it was lost and confused. I blame a little bit on the writers for this flaw. The movie has a very dark gritty feeling/tone throughout the middle and the end of the movie. Some of the choices of characters was sort of a problem for me throughout the movie. This is sometimes a case of movie when the writers never think of common sense in certain scenes of a movie. The fights in this movie is brutal and well choreographed! But the editing of fighting scenes are sloppy and choppy. Peter Jackson did an awesome job capturing the fantasy world in the movie and capture real imagination, which is good thing for fantasy movies like these. The score is soothing and beautifully played. And when ever it comes on in the background I always hum to it because it's that good. The sound editing of dialogue is a little weak but you'll get passed it. But when the action scenes occur the sound is booming and has great quality. I will love to say that I can't wait to see the next movie which is 'The Two Towers' whenever get the time to. To sum it all up, 'Fellowship Of The Ring' was a pretty good film. Not epic in my opinion but pretty close to it! I will loved to give this movie more credit but still I had some of the concerns of the movie with it's poor editing with sound and scenes. Also, I had problems with the script with character decisions and confusing dialogue. And, the movie has some slow boring parts to it that really drags. But besides my concerns this movie is really good in my opinion and is a well made movie. So for those and my previous reasons I will give 'The Lord Of The Rings: Fellowship Of The Ring' an A- grading!

Say what you will about little people, but one thing is for certain and that is they can surely throw one hell of a birthday party. So the time has come as I review six episodic films for the next nine days. I know it seems like a bit of a squeeze, but with a little time and luck I can get through this in no time. Any who, author J.R.R. Tolkien went to his grave knowing that he written four well good fantasy books in his life. The books that I am referring to are The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings trilogy which became one of the first fan bases in the 20th Century to have a huge following. It was not until long after his death that a long-time fanboy and director name Peter Jackson decided to make a film adaptation about it and the result is one to talk about for the ages. I mean sure it has been over ten years since the trilogies came out, but if you watch these films today you would realize that they are still mind blowing from the special effects to the casting. But perhaps I am getting a little ahead of myself here with this, so let's start this off right as I begin my own journey into the unknown and back again.

Where do I begin with this masterpiece? For starters, I absolutely LOVE the visualization and special effects that they put in here for this film. You watch this today and you would believe that this movie was done last year, when in fact it was over ten years ago. Peter Jackson does an astounding job adapting ninety percent of the dialogue from the book and into the movie and what's even better than the dialogue are the actors themselves. Who would have thought that a bunch of actors who played various roles from the eighties and nineties would be spot on with the iconic fantasy characters that they play that it just seems too good to be true. Also for two hours and fifty minutes worth of film it does not feel like it is drag on at all, because you are too involved with the story and the characters and before you even know it, it's all over for part one. Overall, I cannot find anything wrong with it other than a few nit-picks here and there that the film had to cut out from the book mostly because it would have gone way over the three hour mark. Which is why I HIGHLY recommend anyone out there to go see this if you haven't already and if you did, and it has been a couple of years or so, then by all mean re-watch this again.

If the late 70's early 80's had the Star wars trilogy, then the 2000's had this epic fantasy masterclass. Regardless of whether you're a fantasy fan or not this is too good a movie to simply pass up, and it will be one of those movies that given time will prove it to be a classic. The deeper you look into this the more one notices that every single aspect really is a truly impressive accomplishment. The fact that every single sword used by the main characters was made by hand, with extra ones made only for carrying, fighting, etc, then there's the costumes/armor/props all made by teams of many people. They even made artificial trees for gods sake. But really all those things are just extras, what really makes this a unique watch is that it really does feel huge and sweeping, the sense of scale is fantastic and I can't think of anything that even comes close to matching it. What every epic flick needs this has, the cast is great, it's exciting, it has bags of character, it's funny, sad, superbly well made, with a great score and plenty of action. It's also one of very few 2 hour 30 minute + movies ever that leaves the audience wanting more. Since watching it around Christmas 2001 at a packed out cinema, and the many times I've seen it on DVD since, it never fails to impress and charm. All in all near perfect cinematic treat that keeps on giving.

JRR Tolkien wrote, "courage is found in unlikely places." He believed in the idea that no matter how small or unimportant a person is, he or she can accomplished any things. This idea is reflected in his popular book series The Lord of the Rings. Tolkien's epic trilogy, Lord of the Rings comes to life in Peter Jackson's movie adaptation. Peter Jackson was able to take the words of Tolkien and craft them into a beautiful movie that represents Tolkien's novel. 
Tolkein grew up in Birmingham, England. When he was older, he received a degree in Anglo-Saxon and Germanic languages and classis literature. Shortly after this, Tolkien enlisted in the army and served in World War I. Due to illness Tolkien was released from duty and became a professor at Oxford ("John Ronald Reuel Tolkien"). One day while grading a paper Tolkien spontaneously wrote, "In a hole in the ground, there lived a Hobbit (Tolkien)." This was the first line of his award-winning novel The Hobbit. This novel was the first building block in the creation of the world of Middle Earth. It later lead to the creation of the Lord of the Rings. 
Most fantasy stories have no base, but Tolkien's story is rooted in reality. Tolkien was greatly influenced by his experience of fighting during World War I. During this time, he witnessed many horrendous things. Tolkien's utopian home was under threat by the malevolent Central Powers in Europe. These powers began to bleed into other European civilizations and threaten the lives of people who believed they were safe. The Central Powers are a parallel to the evil that exists Mordor. Similar to the Central Powers, the forces in Mordor are spreading across Middle Earth demolishing everything in their way. When Tolkien joined the army, he was deployed to the Somme River and participated in the deadliest battle in British history ("National Geographic"). Every day Tolkien was plague with brutal images of war. These images contributed to dark storyline of The Lord of the Rings. The war left a lasting impression on Tolkien and these events created the foundation for his future stories and provided him with the opportunity to supplement England's missing mythological past with his own stories. 
Although Tolkien's storyline was inspired from wartime events, he wanted to develop a set of stories that could represent England's lost mythology. During his years as a professor Tolkien studied the Anglo-Saxon time period of the fifth and sixth century. The Anglo-Saxons lived in England and they had developed an extensive set of mythological tales. The Anglo-Saxons were illiterate and they had to rely on verbal storytelling .As a result, most of these stories have been lost due to a conquest in the eleventh century ("National Geographic"). Tolkien's passion for this subject gave him the duty to create his own version of these lost tales. 
Nearly forty-seven years later, after the first publication of the trilogy, Peter Jackson directed and wrote the film adaptation of the Tolkien's books. The overall plot of the three movies revolves around the destruction of the one ring. The ring was forged in secrecy by the dark lord Sauron (antagonist) and it was designed to rule all the people of Middle Earth. In order to save Middle Earth a fellowship was formed of nine companions: Aragorn, Gandalf, Boromir, Gimli, Legolas, Pippin, Sam, Merry, and Frodo (protagonist). They are burdened with the mission to take the ring to Mordor and toss the ring into Mt. Doom to destroy it. 
	Unlike other trilogies, The Lord of the Rings movies were filmed simultaneously over an eighteen month time period. This is unconventional for most movie series. Usually the first movie is filmed then the cast and crew return years later to create more movies in the series. This extensive time period allowed for the cast and crew to create three cohesive movies and attempt new, innovative filming techniques. For example, the films were the first to use a live motion capturing system. The crew used this system to create the CGI character Gollum. This allowed the actor Andy Serkis to add more depth to his performance of Gollum. Instead of simply using solely a voiceover for the character, Serkis was able to contribute the motions and facial expressions to this animated character ("Bringing Gollum to Life"). This process has now become widely used in many movies to create a more realistic performance. The extended filming time also provided the opportunity for the crew to fully utilize the beautiful scenery in New Zealand. The gorgeous scenery in the movie contributes to the creation of Middle Earth. The production team was able to merge the real scenery and CGI backgrounds to capture the essence of Middle Earth. 
	The music composer for The Lord of the Rings was Howard Shore. He is a widely popular music composer and has produced music for over eighty-eight movies. Some of his most popular soundtracks included The Aviator, Hugo, The Hobbit, and The Silence of the Lambs. The music he created for The Lord of the Rings remains his most well known piece of work. He has won four Grammys and three Golden Globes for The Lord of the Rings trilogy ("Biography").  To record the music score for the movie, Shore used an unconventional method. Movie soundtracks are now generated through computer programs. However, Shore used a lived orchestra and choir. Shore believed it was his duty to translate the words of Tolkien into music to accurately depict the books' story. While discussing the soundtrack Shore stated, "It was a tremendous experience, translating the words of Tolkien into music ("From Book to Vision")." To bring the story to life, Shore created many leitmotivs for characters and the places in Middle Earth. 
	Leitmotivs were essential to convey the story in the movie to connect themes and ideas. One of the most iconic songs in The Lord of the Rings is titled Concerning Hobbits. This is song is used to represent the hobbits and their place of residency: the Shire. It has a jovial and lighthearted tone that composed of major chords that reflects the personality of the hobbits. Another leitmotiv in the movie is the Fellowship theme. The song is first heard when Sam and Frodo leave the Shire and start their journey. Only one line of the song is used in the scene because the fellowship has not been fully formed. As the journey progresses, the fellowship starts to come together during the Council of Elrond. This meeting was a collection of representatives of Middle Earth who were deciding the fate of the ring. At the end of the meeting Lord Elrond stands up and announces, "you shall be the fellowship of the ring (Jackson)." The Fellowship theme is then played in its fully formed version. This is the only time the audience hears the song in its complete formed. Through out the movie, the fellowship falls apart and the song begins to degrade. By the end of the movie, the fellowship has been split into two and the last remaining line of the song is echoed during the scene ("From Book to Vision"). These are two examples of the leitmotivs that represent the good forces in the movie. Shore also created leitmotivs that represent the evil forces. 
	Tolkien's story focuses on the struggle between good and evil. The music represents this struggle and Shore crafted malicious leitmotivs to counter the righteous leitmotivs. To produce this negative sound, Shore utilized unusual rhythms and chants from male choirs. For example, the leitmotiv for Isengard was written in 5/4-time measure to create an unresolved and uneasy mood. The ring is given several different songs to represents its evil. This ring has three leitmotivs: the power, the voice, and the evil. The voice of the ring was created using an all boy choir to provide a seductive and alluring tone. The power of the ring has a dramatic tone that was composed mostly of strings. This represents the enormous amount of power the ring possesses. Lastly, a chant is combined with a less dramatic version of leitmotiv for the power of the ring ("From Book to Vision"). This creates a very eerie tone. These leitmotivs were essential in giving depth to the evil of Middle Earth.
	The leitmotivs in The Lord of the Rings were very important to convey the storyline. The score helped to create the mood of the scene and identify specific objects or people in the movie. The main theme of good versus evil came alive through the music. Howard Shore's unique music was able to create the culture of Middle Earth through music. 
	The Lord of the Rings quickly became a box office hit due to the combination of the movies innovate cinematography, music, and excellent cast. The three movies grossed over two billion dollars (Rotten Tomatoes). Overall, both critics and fans received the movie very well. Movie critic Michael Sragow stated, "The Fellowship of the Ring is a movie masterpiece thrilling, passionate and wise." The Lord of the Rings trilogy has become a beloved favorite of many people and is regarded by the fans as one of the best movies of all time. 
	The Lord of the Rings trilogy is a timeless story of good versus evil. The story is accompanied by beautifully crafted music, amazing special effects, and talented actors. JRR Peter Jackson was able to bring JRR Tolkien's story alive and create an amazing movie. Tolkien once wrote, "all we have to decide is what to do with the time that is given us." Everyone should at least once utilize the time that is given to them and watch this astounding trilogy.

Lord of the Rings: Fellowship of the Ring
	Lord of the Rings is part of a book trilogy that was also made into three movies. Fellowship of the Ring is the first movie out of the three. The movie came out in December 2001, is rated PG 13 and last about 3 hours. The setting for the movie is Middle Earth, which starts in The Shire and journeys through the land to Mordor.
	The summery of the movie starts out with the hobbit Frodo. Gandalf the Grey, a great wizard, sends Frodo and his friend Sam on a long, perilous journey through Middle Earth. Gandalf sends Frodo to destroy the one very powerful Ring at Mount Doom, which is where it was created. Gandalf accompanies Frodo and Sam on their journey, along with several others including two men, an elf, and a dwarf in which they form The Fellowship. Together The Fellowship face great dangers on their journey to Mordor.
This particular movie is I would say not the best out of the three but it very important. Reading or watching The Hobbit will explain in greater detail of how this all started, which is the prequel of this series. Some may have to watch the movie two or three times to really understand what is going on, especially in the beginning. The history of the movie is short and can be confusing for the rest of the movie when not fully understanding what everything is about. To make the story flow better watch the Hobbit movies and then watch Lord of the Rings. Like almost all beginnings this first movie starts out slow but does pick up towards the middle. Other than the few minor details of what may not be the best, this movie is a great one.
The series Lord of the Rings is one of my all time favorite series. Fellowship of the Ring does a great job starting out and leading up to what will happen in the other movies. In this movie you learn who every character is and why they are of importance. Throughout the movie there is several battles with suspense like when you wonder what will happen to Gandalf when with Saruman, battle between the orcs and the Fellowship, and also what will happen to Frodo when he is the Ring keeper. There is also a love story within the movie which grabs the attention for romance, that way its not just action and battles. There is a great mixture of romance, action, suspense, and geekiness. The film itself was great with the effects and costume/makeup props. Parts of the movie have certain songs to specific scenes, like a dooming type song every time Saruman or the orcs appear and a more light cheery sound when The Fellowship journey in the open fields. The landscapes were fantastic, large and open like you would imagine the olden times. The characters are all very interesting and different because the story includes men, elves, dwarves, hobbits, wizards, and orcs. There is also another character Gollum that has become the most popular among this series and is the one character many people know of even if theyve never seen the series. Gollum was once a hobbit but the ring transformed him into an unknown creature that has unusual long life. He also has split personalities so throughout the movie he refers to himself as Sméagol or Gollum and the two are very distinct. The orcs are all costumes and makeup which when viewing them up-close, it took many hours to perfect. The battle scenes of the movie were perfectly laid out and you fell as if youre there in the fight. Stunt doubles did great in the battles and the actors did a phenomenal job in really capturing their character. Each one really had there own personality in the movie and theres not a character that is disappointing at all. The ending of the movie was a great place to leave off for the next movie, ends in a small cliff hanger but it does lead right into the next movie which is a great transition. The producers wrote a fantastic movie and took their time creating this masterpiece. They took every aspect of the book and created it to life. J.R.R. Tolkien did a great job writing this series and the people who made this movie happen really captured what the book has laid out.  Even though the movie is long it is worth watching when alone or during date night. Out of everything, I would recommend this movie to anyone because it is truly a great movie that you can watch over and over again without ever getting bored.
In conclusion, I would rate this movie around 4-5 stars. Great story line, awesome character development, and the set up of this movie was fantastic. I highly recommend watching this movie along with the rest of the Lord of the Rings and also The Hobbit. Its like a bag of chips, you cant just do with one! If you are looking for something different to watch other than just the Michael Bay blowing things up or the sappy love story movies, then this is the best one for you.  When watching this movie, it takes your attention to really capture the full story line and to understand it. J.R.R. Tolkien is a fantastic author and this is a great movie that really represents what the book is about.
Definitely the best scene is the ending it is truly epic. It's a must see for any Tolkien lover!!!

A lot of film lovers have that one movie that inspired them to work in movies or made them fall in love with movies. For a lot of people that movie was Ben-hur due to the epic film making and a classic revenge story with Religious undertones, for others it was Star Wars(1977) due to the advancement in special effects at the time, mine is without a shadow of a doubt the fellowship of the ring which i believe is hands down the best movie of this epic trilogy. Now this is the only trilogy out of all the so-called great trilogies(Star wars,Indiana Jones, Toy story, The dark knight trilogy) that I view as one very long movie.But if I was forced to choose a favorite this would be mine because I think the Two Towers drags a bit(hey it's expected since it's the middle chapter) and I felt exhausted after watching the final 40 minutes of Return of the Kings. The way the movie introduces the story is astonishing. This movie features some fictional places such as the shire that you wish were real. The soundtrack is perfect and completely captures the themes of the movie- friendship,mystery,hope,loss. This movie made me fall in love with New Zealand(I bet tourism sky-rocketed after this movie) and I really want to visit their country someday.There were about 50 consecutive minutes that just contained the best scenes of the entire trilogy in my opinion from moria's door, to the sea creature, to balin's tomb, to the battle of balin's tomb, to the belrog, to the "death" of Gandalf, to the music of the scene, to the reaction of the aftermath, to the beauty of New Zealand, great scene followed by a great scene, followed by another great scene etc.You also have to take into account that this trilogy was filmed back to back,so the risk that the studio took was huge I believe that the lord of the ring trilogy not only is an achievement  in movie/movie making but an achievement in life in general.I will forever cherish the trilogy and It will be continued to be seen by generations.Of course I'm going to give this movie a 5/5

Even though most people would think of The Hobbit coming first, Peter Jackson took the brave step of choosing to debut The Fellowship as his first. The actors were well chosen for this kind of Motion Picture, and the actresses, well... some of them are "weird", the simplest ay to put it. The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack by Howard Shore was fantastically put together. Needless to say, the Soundtrack was perfect. It is amazing. The Lord of the Rings is a perfect trilogy in many ways. The storyline is so complex you have to watch it more than once. However even by your first viewing you're going to love the characters and visual effects. The Fellowship of the Ring is a great start to this trilogy. The characters are all wonderfully put together. Frodo is a good hero in the sense that he does take his responsibility if reluctantly and never gives up on his duty. Sam is the most loyal best friend any hero could ask for, and Sam remains by his side throughout the series. Gandalf is wize and powerful and one of my personal favorite characters. The villains aren't fantastic for the most part, but that's because the real villain is the Ring. That's how we see more of what Sauron's personality was. Saruman is another good villain and is the perfect example of a hero turned to the dark side perhaps even better an example than Darth Vader. The effects in this movie are amazing, and the story is enough to keep you interested for the long running time. Like it or hate it, you'll most likely have to watch this one at least twice.

"FRODO AND THE ONE RING TO RULE THEM ALL"

- 'Lord of the Rings - The Fellowship of the Ring' is a 2001 epic fantasy film from director Peter Jackson (King Kong), based on the first volume of J.R.R. Tolkien's novel trilogy with the same name. A visually stunning fantasy adventure, perfect to the littlest detail and highly recommendable. I must say the books are too long for me, but this movie could have kept on going. It's that good. With the amazing talents of Elijah Wood (The Faculty), Ian McKellen (X-men Trilogy), Sean Astin (The Goonies), Viggo Mortensen (A History of Violence), Sean Bean (Game of Thrones), Orlando Bloom (Kingdom of Heaven), John Rhys-Davies (Indiana Jones films) , Hugo Weaving (The Matrix Trilogy), Liv Tyler (Armaggedon), Christopher Lee (Star Wars prequels), Cate Blanchett (Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull), Ian Holm (Alien) and Andy Serkis (The Prestige) as Gollum. A must-see film! 

An ancient ring is given to the hobbit Frodo Baggins (Wood) by his uncle Bilbo (Holm), who found it years ago in the cave of a creature named Gollum (Serkis) during one of his adventures. Wizard Gandalf the Grey (McKellen) senses that this ring has unspeakable power, wanted by the forces of evil. Before seeking advice from his fellow wizard Saruman (Lee) Gandalf sends Frodo and his friend Sam (Astin) away to an Inn where he will meet them. Along the way the two hobbits are accompanied by their neighbors Merry and Peppin and followed by nine dark horsemen. At the Inn they meet the lone ranger Aragorn (Mortenson) who helps them fight off the pursuers. But when Frodo is injured, the group has to let him go with the beautiful Elf princess Arwin (Tyler), who takes the hobbit to her hometown. 

There Frodo awakens with his friends by his side. Gandalf has also showed up, but brings bad news: Saruman has joined the army of darkness who wants to claim the ring. During a special council Frodo accepts the quest to go to the land of Mordor to destroy the ring in the fires of mount Doom.  A fellowship is formed as his three friends, Gandalf and Aragorn join him on this dangerous journey, as well as Legolas (Bloom) the Elf, Gimli the Dwarf (Rhys-Davies) and Boromir the Human (Bean). The group will need to pass through Mines of Moira and the woods of Lothérien, home of Lady Galadriel (Blanchett). Will the Fellowship succeed?

Generally speaking I don't like the LOTR series.  I acknowledge they look great but for me I hate them because I was continually let down throughout them.  Far too often in the LOTR series I think the story builds up these great idea's or characters and them lets me down whenever something big is supposed to happen.
For example: The Ring Wraiths.  Great name...great design..great backstory and they do a good job of showing how afraid of them everyone was.

oh...let me put it out there that I never read the books and I think any discussion of the books is irrelevant since I'm watching a movie and that's what I'll judge it by. Back to the wraiths..

I LOVED these guys and couldn't wait to seem them flex their muscle (or bone).  In the first movie, a big wave in the river washed them away.  After such a build up, the wave was a little anti-climatic.  The wave wan't all that impressive either.  I'll call that a flawed execution of the idea (water will get rid of them).  There was also a scene where they came upon the hobbit in a derelict tower and I don't remember anything cool about  it (I need to rewatch these films I agree..it's just I've never been interested enough to spend that much time again).  And finally at the end of the film during the big battle scene it looks like we're going to get to see them do something really cool and what happens? The wraith gets killed before he ever does anything cool.  Let down again!

Gandalf?  HAH!  I love the idea of the most powerful wizard and he certainly looks the part but aside from one scene where he was swinging his stick and knocking bad guys around, what giant magical things did he do?!  He made his staff into a giant flashlight?!  That's it! I waited hours upon hours to see him make a big flahslight?!  Huge let down!   Yes the Balrog was cool and he has a great line in the scene but we don't get to really see what makes Gandalf so magical.  

I've got more but I'm sure no one will read this.

I want to add that I am shocked by how much I absolutely love the 2 new Hobbit movies (Hobbit and Desolation of Smaug).  Hell..I give those films 5 stars.  Love them and I can easily say that I think Desolation of Smaug is the best of all these films.

When little-known director at the time Peter Jackson decided to create an epic film adaptation of JRR Tolkien's timeless Lord of the Rings books, stakes were raised extremely high, especially when Ralph Bashki's animation version of the story was an epic disaster back in 1978 (though I never watched it) and when it was decided to film the trilogy back-to-back-to-back. Thankfully, when the first chapter of the film trilogy, The Fellowship of the Ring, was released in 2001, it was an epic smash, winning 4 Academy Awards, 13 total nominations including Best Picture, which is rare for a big blockbuster. Jackson's LOTR trilogy were game-changers in the fantasy genre, and The Fellowship of the Ring begins this great franchise off with a ginormous bang, leading up to an strong epic cliffhanger that definitely made audiences begging to see the sequels.

In the world of Middle-earth, hobbit Frodo Baggins (Elijah Wood) gains possession of a mysterious magical ring from his mysterious uncle Bilbo (Ian Holm). When it's revealed that the ring is the One Ring, a powerful ring formally owned by the fallen Lord Sauron, Frodo, along with a band of heroes, known as The Fellowship of the Ring, leads into an epic quest to the fires of Mount Doom to destroy the ring and defeat Sauron once and for all before he regains possession of it.

Joining the Fellowship includes Sean Astin as hobbit (and Frodo's personal friend) Sam, 
Dominic Monaghan and Billy Boyd as comical hobbits Merry and Pippin, Ian McKellen as wise wizard Gandalf the Grey, Viggo Mortenson as ranger Aragorn/Strider, Orlando Bloom as bow-shooting elf Legolas, John Rhys-Davies as the humorous dwarf Gimli, and Sean Bean as the suspicious human Boromir.

Also appearing in this epic masterpiece includes Hugo Weaving as wise elf Elrond, Liv Tyler as Aragon's elf lover Arwen, Cate Blanchett as beautiful elf princess Galadriel, Christopher Lee as the villainous wizard Saruman the White, and Andy Serkis as the mysterious creature Gollum.

Jackson created the world of Middle-earth on film via filming in the lovely New Zealand, and it's gorgeous. Had Jackson chosen to create this incredible fantasy world via green-screen or by Hollywood backlot, then the film definitely wouldn't have worked as great as it was. The cinematic shots of New Zealand landscapes are jaw-dropping and amazing to look at. Also the visuals for this film, created by Weta Workshop, are also amazing. Weta brilliantly manages to combine CGI and practical effects in the most astounding way possible, CGI for things like cave trolls and a demon called "The Shadow" and practical for Orcs and the Urukai. Whatever Jackson and Weta did, this is visual filmmaking at it's finest in the 21st Century.

Considering it's a fantasy epic, each scene presented in this film sounds like it could have happened in real-life. No there wouldn't be magical rings or hobbits or dwarves or elves, but the thought of a ruthless ruler returning to power and attempting to destroy the world is actually a scary thought. Jackson brilliantly combines fantasy elements and reality and, with the excellent Tolkien source material, creates a wonderful fantasy epic. I was also impressed with the action sequences as well, with my personal favorite being a sequence where Gandalf confronts "The Shadow" in a really dark and scary mine controlled by Orcs, hollering "YOU SHALL NOT PASS!". Other strong sequences are the opening battle scene during the origins of the ring scene, Gandalf's epic battle with Saruman, Arwen's fight against evil hooded figures, and the finale with the Fellowship in action against Saruman's created Orc army, the Urukai. In three hours, Jackson has created the ultimate fantasy experience without overdoing it on heavy action.

There's a huge heavy cast involved in Fellowship of the Ring, and each one involved did an amazing acting performance here. Elijah Wood is excellent as Frodo and shows dedication to one who wants to defeat evil. Other noteworthy performances include Viggo Mortenson as exiled heir Aragorn, who excels the most in the excellent action sequences, Ian McKellen as Gandalf, who's performance was Oscar-worthy in emotional depth and pure awesomeness, and veteran actor Christopher Lee as Saruman, the wizard assistant to Sauron.

And last, Howard Shore's score for this film is spectacular. There's loads of exciting themes here, from the fellowship, The Shire, the ring, Saruman, and even one for Sean Bean's Boromir character. The score definitely deserved it's Oscar win, due to how strong Shore's cues are and how emotional Shore puts into his work.

It could have been a disaster in the hands of an amateur, but with Peter Jackson at the helm, The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Rings is that epic of a fantasy film, with perfect acting all around, stellar visuals, a great score, and Jackson's approach to the world of Middle-earth. The Lord of the Rings franchise is that rare book-to-movie franchise where there's detail and perfection in every way mentioned, and Peter Jackson is a modern genius filmmaker. The Fellowship of the Ring is an excellent beginning, and the franchise has only started.
